div.p: THE SCHOOL FOR ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.
THE SCHOOL for ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. J. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THE Comedy of Le Glorieux, by M. Nericault Deſtouches, is the baſis on which The School for Arrogance has been formed. From that I have taken the plan, ſeveral of the characters, and ſome of the ſcenes. Difference of arrangement, additional incidents, and what I deem to be eſſential changes of character, have all been introduced. The Count has but little reſemblance to the original: Lucy and Mac Dermot none. Lady Peckham is a new character, and was firſt ſuggeſted by a friend; who, conceiving highly of the contraſt which exiſts in life, between the pride of rank and the pride of riches, induſtriouſly ſought to ſtimulate and rouſe my imagination.

The ſubject of the piece is greatly intereſting to morals, and highly worthy of the Theatre. Conſcious of the great effects a perfect Comedy might have produced, I regret the imperfections of the preſent. Some good it will do: I regret that it cannot do more. Perſuaded as I am of the moral
dignity of the ſtage, I cheriſh an enthuſiaſtic wiſh to ſee the dramatic art ſurpaſs even all its former ſublime efforts. Among the pleaſures of the imagination, how frequently has its place been the firſt! Happy indeed ſhould I be, could my ſucceſs add the ſmalleſt impulſe to the exertions of Genius: ineffably happy, would but this noble art once more boldly aſſert its rank; and render itſelf, not only the general love and delight of mankind, but the veneration of the wiſe.

It is with peculiar pleaſure that I here acknowledge how much I am indebted to the conduct of Mr. Marſhal; who, in conſequence of the prejudices which it was imagined Mr. Harris laboured under, reſpecting me, acted, for a time, in my behalf, as the author of the piece. Though anxiouſly zealous for its ſucceſs, he ſtill continued impartially attentive to the intereſts of all parties; and ſacrificed his own feelings to promote what he conceived to be a public good.

The tribute of juſtice is alſo due to Mr. Harris. This tribute I am happy to have an opportunity to pay. And, that I may
now be conſiſtent, as I always have been, in my private and public language to Mr. Harris, I will here inſert a copy of a letter which I wrote to him, when the comedy had been twice performed.

body.p:
I HAVE patiently waited the proper moment in which to write to you. That moment I hope is now come. I ſhould be guilty of injuſtice, were I any longer to delay expreſſing my ſenſe of the propriety with which you have acted, relatively to The School for Arrogance, after you had every reaſon to ſuppoſe it mine. Such conduct, Sir, is highly honourable; and is not only productive of the beſt effects, but muſt ſecure the beſt and moſt permanent applauſe. That you had conceived diſadvantageous ideas of me I knew; though I have no doubt but I ſhall ultimately convince you that, even ſuppoſing me to be miſtaken, my motives have been laudable ***** A ſingle phraſe, which relates entirely to myſelf, is here omitted.. With me you were
irritated; but you had the juſtice to forget the man, and promote the intereſts of the piece. This I hold it my duty to ſay to the world at large.

closer.salute: I am, Sir, Your obliged humble ſervant,

body.p: Mr. Harris kindly expreſſed the ſatisfaction which his own private feelings received, from this letter; nor can there be a doubt but that the propriety of his conduct, under ſuch circumſtances, will be as agreeable to himſelf, and as pleaſing to the public, as it has been to me.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: Spoken by Mr. BERNARD, in the character of a News-hawker.
div.stage: After ſounding and calling "Great news!" without, enter with a poſtman's horn, newſpapers, cap, and livery.

lg.l: GREAT news! Great news! Extraordinary news!
Who'll buy, or give three half-pence to peruſe?
(Sounds) Great news!—Pray did you call, Sirs? Here am I!
Of wants and wanted I've a large ſupply!
Of fire and murder, marriage, birth and death,
Here's more than I can utter in a breath!
Rapes, riots, hurricanes, routs, rogues, and faro!
Famine and flames in Turkey, and the plague at Cairo!
Here's tincture for the gums, which dentiſts make;
Whoſe teeth eat moſt when other people's ache.
Here are rich ſoups, hams, tongues, oils, ſauce, ſour krout:
And here's the grand ſpecific for the gout!
Here's turtle newly landed; lamb houſe-fed:
And here a wife and five ſmall children wanting bread.
Wholeſale and retail Britiſh ſpirits here:
And here's the dying ſpeech of poor ſmall-beer!
Here are tall men, ſhort women, and fat oxen:
And here are Sunday ſchools, and ſchools for boxing;
Here ruin'd rakes for helpmates advertiſe;
And only want 'em handſome, rich, and wiſe.
Great news! Here's money lent on bond, rare news!
By honeſt, tender-hearted, chriſtian Jews!
Here are promotions, dividends, rewards;
A liſt of bankrupts, and of new-made lords.
Here the debates at length are, for the week:
And here the deaf and dumb are taught to ſpeak.
Here Hazard, Goodluck, Shergold, and a band
Of gen'rous gentlemen, whoſe hearts expand
With honour, rectitude, and public ſpirit,
Equal in high deſert, with equal merit,
Divide their tickets into ſhares, and quarters:
And here's a ſervant-maid found hanging in her garters!
Here! Here's the fifty thouſand, ſold at ev'ry ſhop!
And here's the Newgate calendar—and drop.
Rare news! Strange news! Extraordinary news!
Who would not give three-halfpence to peruſe?
'Sblues! I forgot—Great news, again, I ſay!
To-night, at Covent Garden, a new play!
(In raptures) Oh! I'll be there! With Jack, our printer's devil!
We're judges, we! Know when to clap, or cavil!
We've heard our preſſmen talk of, of—of Rome and Greece!
And have read Harry-Harry-Harry Stotle's maſter piece!
When we have paid our ſhilling, we're the town!
As wiſely can find fault as thoſe who pay their crown!
Nay we, like them, if it be bad or good,
Can talk, as faſt as, as—as if we underſtood!
Oh! I'll be there; get the firſt row; and, with my ſtaff,
I'll act the trunk-maker, thump, roar, encore, and laugh!
The prompter's boy has call'd our Jack aſide;
And ſays the Play's to cure the world of pride!
That rich folks will no longer think they're born
To cruſh the weak, and laugh the poor to ſcorn!
The great 'twill teach that virtue, wit, and merit,
They may perchance poſſeſs, but can't inherit!
That learning, wiſdom, genius, truth, and worth,
Are far more rich and rare than ribbands, rank, and birth!
Lord! Lord! Whoever heard of ſuch a ſcheme?
Teach ſenſe to wealth and pride! Your poets always dream!
Could he do this, there's no one will deny
That News! Strange news! would be the gen'ral cry.

div.head: THE SCHOOL FOR ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.
ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE I. [The Houſe of Sir PAUL PECKHAM.]
Enter LYDIA followed by MAC DERMOT.

sp.speaker: LYDIA.
sp.p: ONCE again, Mr. Mac Dermot, have done with this nonſenſe.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah, and why ſo ſcoffiſh? Sure now a little bit of making love—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Do me the favour to anſwer my queſtions. The Count, your maſter, is in love with Miſs Lucy Peckham?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and you may ſay that.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Is he really well born?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! As for that, honey, let him alone. The nobleſt blood of France, aye, and what is better, of Ireland too, trickles to his finger's ends. The Villars and the O'Connollies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And he wiſhes to marry into the family of the Peckhams?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The divle a bit, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: He is viry willing to marry the young Lady, but not her family. His pride and his paſſion have had many a tough battle about that, d'ye ſee. Only think! A direct deſcindant of the former kings of Ireland, and collateral couſin to a priſent peer of France, to beſmear and beſmoulder his dignity by rubbing it againſt porter butts, vinegar caſks, and beer barrels.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Miſs Lucy is indeed a lovely girl, animated to exceſs, and ſometimes apparently giddy and flighty: but ſhe has an excellent underſtanding, and a noble heart; and theſe are ſuperior to birth, which is indeed a thing of mere accident.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and that it is—I, a ſimple Iriſhman, as I am—why now, I would have been born a duke, had they been civil enough to have aſked my conſint.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The Count fell in love with her at the convent, to which ſhe was ſent to improve her French.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: And where I think you firſt met with her?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Yes—ſhe ſaw me friendleſs, and conceived a generous and diſintereſted affection
for me.—He has followed her to England; has taken apartments in our neighbourhood, and lives in ſplendour—yet is not rich.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Um, um.—No—But then he is a Colonel in the Iriſh brigade; and, beſide his pay, has ſacrit ſupplies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and I don't believe he knows that himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: That's ſtrange!—His pride is exceſſive.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To ſpake the truth, that now is his failing.—An if it was not for that, oh! he would be the jewel of a maſter!—He trates his infariors with contimpt, keeps his diſtance with his aquals, and values the rubbiſhing duſt of his great grandfathers above diamonds!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: His character is in perfect contraſt to that of his humble rival, Sir Samuel Sheepy; who, even when he addreſſes a footman, is all bows and affability; whoſe chief diſcourſe is, Yes, if you pleaſe, and, No, thank you; and who, in the company of his miſtreſs, ſtammers, blunders, and bluſhes, like a great boy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What is it you till me? He the rival of the Count my maſter! That old—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: A bachelor, and only fifty; rich, of a good family, and a great favourite with Lady Peckham, by never having the courage to contradict her.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, there now! You talk of the Count's pride! Here is this city lady as proud as ten counts! Her own coach horſes, ready harneſſed, don't carry their heads higher! And then ſhe is as inſolent, and as vulgar, and—Hem!

div.stage: Enter Lady PECKHAM and Sir SAMUEL SHEEPY, followed by two Footmen, in very ſmart morning jackets.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Here, fellers—go with theſe here cards [Footmen receive each a parcel of large cards, and are going] Oh! Tell that there butler to come to me—inſtantly.—And—Do you hear?—Vhen you comes back, get thoſe diſmal heads of yourn better powder'd; put on your noo liveries, and make yourſelves a little like chriſtians.—Theſe creeters are no better nur brootes, Sir Samooel! They are all ſo monſtrous low, and wulgar!—I have a party to-night; I hopes you vill make von?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, vhere is this butler?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am here, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Is all the furniter rubb'd?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: All, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The m'ogany bright?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: As bees-wax can make it, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Bow pots in the china jars?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The picters on the hall ſtair-caſe ſcoured?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Clean, my Lady!—But, I— (heſitating)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You! You vhat?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am afraid their eyes and noſes will ſoon diſappear.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Pſha!—Feller!—Are the noo prints come home?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And the karakatoors hung up in the drawing room?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: All, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You ſhall come and ſee 'em, Sir Samooel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip has exquiſite taſte.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Samooel!—Vell, feller?

sp.speaker: "Butler.
sp.p: My Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat do you ſtand gaping at?

sp.speaker: "Butler.
sp.p: My Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vill you begone, feller?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh!—Yes, my Lady; (Aſide) and thank you too! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: So, Miſs! is Sir Paul come to town?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I have not ſeen him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir Paul generally ſleeps at our country ſeat, at Hackney.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A pleaſant retreat, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Waſtly! A wery paradiſe!—Vhere is my daughter, Miſs?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I don't know, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And vhy don't you know? Pleaſe to go and tell her Sir Samooel is here. [Exit Lydia.]—A young purſon that my daughter has taken under her purtection.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Seems mild and modeſt, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Not too much of that, Sir Samooel.—Who (Surveying Mac Dermot)—pray, who are you, young man?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I!—Faith, my Lady, I—I am—myſilf: Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count's gintleman.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Gentleman!—Gentleman, indeed!—Count's gentleman!—Ha!—A kind of mungrel Count, Sir Samooel; half French,
half Iriſh! As good a gentleman, I ſuppoſe, as his footman here! I believes you have ſeen him though?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I think I once had the honor to meet him here, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: An honor, Sir Samooel, not of my ſeeking, I aſſure you! Aſpires to the hand of Miſs Loocy Peckham!—He!—An outlandiſh French foriner!—I hates 'em all! I looks upon none on 'em as no better nur ſavages! Vhat do they vant vith us? Vhy our money, to be ſure! A parcel of beggars!—I viſhes I vus Queen of England for von day only! I vould uſher my orders to take and conquer 'em all, and tranſport 'em to the plantations, inſtead of negurs.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I have heard, my Lady, that the Count was my rival.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: He your rival, Sir Samooel! He! A half bred, higglety-pigglety, Iriſh, French fortin hunter rival you indeed!— [Enter Lydia.]—Vell, Miſs! Vhere is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: In her own apartment, Madam, dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: She'll be down preſently, Sir Samooel—Gentleman indeed! The Count's Gentleman! Ha! Pride and Poverty!

div.stage: [Exeunt Lady Peckham and Sir Samuel Sheepy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: (Highly affronted) Pride!—By the holy footſtool, but your Ladyſhip and Lucifer are a pair!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Then I will be after going.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No, no; ſtay where you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah! My ſweet dear Liddy! You are the angel I wiſhed firſt to meet! Come to my— (Running up to her.)—Why how now, huſſey? Why ſo ſhy?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Reſerve your tranſports, Sir, for Lady Peckham.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lady!—But who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Mr. Mac Dermot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! I remember—ſervant to the Count, my intended ſon-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The viry ſame, Sir. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I hear an excellent character of your maſter. They tell me he is a fine, hearty, dauntleſs, ſwaggering fellow! If ſo, he is a man of family, and the very huſband for my Lucy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, thin, and he is all that!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: As for this Sir Samuel Sheepy, he ſhall decamp—A water drinker! A bowing, ſcraping, ſimpering, ceremonious Sir! Never contradicts any body!—Dammee! An old bachelor! And he! He have the impudence to make love to my fine, young, ſpirited wench!—But he is my Lady's choice!—Is ſhe within?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe we ſhall have a fine breeze on this ſubject! But, what! Am I not the monarch, the Grand Seignior of this houſe? Am I not abſolute? Shall I not diſpoſe of my daughter as I pleaſe? Do you hear, young man? Go, preſent my compliments to the Count, and tell him I mean to give him a call this morning.

div.stage: [Lydia makes ſigns to Mac Dermot to ſtay.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I am waiting for him here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Waiting for him here, Sir! No, Sir! You cannot wait for him here, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And, Sir! Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count bid me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And I bid you, Sir—Pack! Begone! [Exit Mac Dermot.]—Now we're alone, my dear Lydia—Why, where are you going, huſſey?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Didn't you hear my Lady call?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Call? No.—And if ſhe did, let her call.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you would not have me offend her?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Offend! Let me ſee who dare be offended with you in this houſe! It is my will that you ſhould be the Sultana!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You, my Queen of Hearts! You! My houſe, my wealth, my ſervants, myſelf, all are yours!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You talk unintelligibly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Do I? Why then I'll ſpeak plainer.—I am in love with you! You are a delicious creature, and I am determined to make your fortune!—I'll take you a houſe up in Mary-lebone; a neat ſnug box; hire you ſervants, keep you a carriage, buy you rings, clothes, and jewels, and come and ſup with you every evening!—Do you underſtand me now?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perfectly, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, and—hay!—Does not the plan tickle your fancy? Do not your veins tingle, your heart beat, your—hay? What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
I really, Sir, don't know what to ſay—except that I cannot comply, unleſs a
Lady, whom I think it my duty to conſult, ſhould give her conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What Lady? Who?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Lady Peckham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My wife!—Zounds! Are you mad? Tell my wife?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I ſhall further aſk the advice of your ſon and daughter, who will wonder at your charity, in taking a poor orphan like me under your protection; will be happy to ſee themſelves ruined for my ſake, and will profit by the example of ſo venerable a father.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Poh! Nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: A little farther off, if you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nearer! Angel! Nearer!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'll raiſe the houſe, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Help!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My handkerchief! You ſweet—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia! Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How now, Sir!— [Aſide to Lydia.] Hem!—Say it was a mouſe—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir?—What do you want, Sir? Who ſent for you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I perceive you are not well, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: How were you taken?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Taken!— [Aſide] Young ſcoundrel!—Take yourſelf away, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Sir! You tremble! Your looks are diſordered! Your eyes wild!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] Here's a dog!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Be ſo obliging, Miſs Lydia, as to run and inform Lady Peckham how ill my father is!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, you imp! [Stopping Lydia] Lydia! Stay where you are—You audacious!—Will you begone?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That I certainly will not, Sir, while I ſee you in ſuch a way!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Way, Sir!—Very well, Sir!—Very well!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I'll reach you a chair, Sir—Pray ſit down—Pray cool yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, that I were cooling you in a horſepond!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You are growing old, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You lie, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You ſhould be more careful of yourſelf—Shall I ſend for a phyſician?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] Dammee, but I'll phyſic you! I'll—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Your ſoup is ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Knew your worſhip's hour—Never made better in my life—Rich and high! Juſt to your worſhip's palate.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, fellow, don't you ſee I'm very ill?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ill, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That my eyes are wild, that I tremble, am old, and want a phyſician?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Lord! Sir Paul! I have been your phyſician for theſe fifteen years!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I tell you, I'm ill; and want cooling!
Aſk that ſcoundrel elſe—I'm dying! So ſerve up your doſe—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Yes, your worſhip. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Muttering as he goes off] A ſly, invidious—The demure dog has a mind to her himſelf—Yes, yes!—Oh! Dammee, pitiful Peter, but I'll fit you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Shrugging] I do.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I muſt leave this family.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Leave! Why, charming Lydia, will you afflict me thus? Have I not declared my purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Which cannot be accompliſhed. You promiſe marriage, but your father will never conſent.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Then we will marry without his conſent.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, no! Do not hope it! When I marry, it ſhall be to render both my huſband and myſelf reſpectable, and happy: not to embitter, not to diſhonour both.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A perſon, who calls himſelf Mr. Dorimont, enquires for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens! Can it be? Shew him up inſtantly. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You ſeem alarmed!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No, no! Overjoyed!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I ſcarcely can tell you. A gentleman who uſed to viſit me in the convent.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Have you been long acquainted?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Little more than two years; during which he was my monitor, conſoler, and guide

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Seeing him before he enters] His appearance—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Is poor; but his heart is rich in benevolence. Pray leave us. [Exit Edmund.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Running to meet him] Ah! Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am happy to have found you once again.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, Sir, has brought you to England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Buſineſs; part of which was to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You have been always generous and kind—Yet I am ſorry you ſhould ſee me thus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why? [Eagerly] What are you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: An humble dependant—A lady's companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Alas! Why did you leave the convent without informing me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: 'Twas unexpected.—You had forborne your viſits; and I feared death, or ſome misfortune. At my mother's deceaſe, the young lady with whom I live having an affection for me, and ſeeing me deſerted, offered to take me with her to England, promiſing I ſhould rather be her friend than her companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And has ſhe kept her word?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: On her part faithfully, tenderly!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: That is ſome conſolation!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: She has a mother, who does not fail to make inſeriority feelingly underſtand itſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [With ſome emotion] Indeed!— [Collecting himſelf] But with whom were you in ſuch earneſt converſation when I entered?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The brother of my young lady: a gentleman worthy your eſteem.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And worthy yours?—You bluſh!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Do you blame me for being juſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No—He is rich, young, and handſome.—Do you often meet?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You are lovely, inexperienced, and unprotected!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Fear nothing—I ſhall not eaſily forget myſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Earneſtly] I hope not.—But what does he ſay?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: That he loves me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No—He offers me ſecret marriage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Secret marriage!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I ſee the danger, and wiſh to ſhun it.—You may find me ſome place of refuge in France.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Can you ſo eaſily renounce all the flattering proſpects love has raiſed?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; and not only them, but love itſelf, when it is my duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Noble-minded girl!—Remain where you are—Nay, indulge your hopes; for know, your lover will be honoured by your hand.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!—Honoured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Honoured!—By birth you are greatly his ſuperior.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Can you be ſerious?—Oh, trifle not
with a too trembling heart!—Why did my mother conceal this ſecret from me?—Or, if true, why die and leave it unrevealed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: There were reaſons—She was not your mother.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Not!—Oh, ſir! You have conjured up ten thouſand buſy thoughts!—Is my mother living?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Why has he ſo long forſaken me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: That muſt be told hereafter. Be patient—wait the event.—You are acquainted, I think, with Count Conolly Villars?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He viſits here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I have buſineſs with him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! I fear you will meet a cool reception! Your humble appearance and his pride will but ill agree.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Fear not—My buſineſs is to lower his pride.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir! He may inſult you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Humble though I myſelf am, I hope to teach him humility. To viſit you, and to accompliſh this, was the purport of my journey.—Adieu for the preſent—Think on what I have ſaid; and, though by birth you are noble, remember, virtue alone is true nobility.

div.stage: [Lydia rings. Exit Mr. Dorimont, and enter Lucy: her dreſs more characteriſtic of the girl than of the woman; and her manner full of life, but tempered by the moſt delicate ſenſibility.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, Lydia! Any news for me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Mr. Mac Dermot has been here, with
the Count's compliments; but in reality to ſee if Lady Peckham were at home. You know how much he wiſhes to avoid her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes; and I don't wonder at it.—She has juſt been with me, uſhering her orders, as ſhe calls it.—"I deſires, Miſs, you vill receive Sir Samooel Sheepy as your intended ſpouſe."—And ſo ſhe has ſent me here to be courted; and the inamorato is coming, as ſoon as he can take breath and courage!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But why, my dear, do you indulge yourſelf in mocking your mamma?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lydia, I muſt either laugh or cry; and, though I laugh, I aſſure you it is often with an aching heart.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My dear girl!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hope, however, you will own there is no great harm in laughing a little at this charming Adonis, this whimſical lover of mine!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps not.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What can his reaſon be for making love to me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: There's a queſtion! Pray, my dear, do you never look in your glaſs?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—yes—But does he never look in his glaſs too?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps his ſight begins to decay.—But are not you alarmed?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Do not you love the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—Yes.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Well! And you know how violent and prejudiced Lady Peckham is!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Perfectly! But I have Sir Paul on my ſide; and, as for Sir Samuel, he was dandled ſo
long in the nurſery, and is ſtill ſo much of the aukward, baſhful boy, that he will never dare to put the queſtion directly to me; and I am determined never to underſtand him till he does.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Don't leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing with trepidation] Madam—Hem!—Madam—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Curtſying and mimicking] Sir—Hem! Sir— [Aſide to Lydia] Count his bows!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam, I—Hem!—I am afraid—I am troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir—Hem!—A gentleman of your merit—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Continues bowing through moſt of the ſcene] Oh, Madam!—I am afraid—Hem!—You are buſy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Curtſying to all his bows] Sir—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Do me the honour to bid me begone.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you would not have me guilty of rudeneſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] What a blunder!—Madam—Hem!—I aſk ten thouſand pardons!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Good manners require—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: That I ſhould begone without bidding. [Going]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] I ſuppoſe I'm wrong again▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I didn't ſay ſo, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Turning quick] Didn't you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A perſon of your politeneſs, breeding, and accompliſhments—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] She's laughing at me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ought to be treated with all reverence. [Curtſying with ironic gravity.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] Yes! She's making a fool of me!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir!—Were you pleaſed to ſpeak, Sir?—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Not a word, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This will be a witty converſation.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir—Hem!—You have ſomething to communicate.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!—Hem!—Yes, Madam, I mean no, Madam—No—Nothing—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Nothing—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Then may I take the liberty, Sir, to enquire—Hem!—What the purport of your viſit is?—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: The—the—the—Hem!—The—purport is—Hem!—I—I have really forgotten!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, pray, Sir, take time to recollect yourſelf—Hem!—I am ſure, Sir Samuel—Hem!—You have ſomething to ſay to me—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes—No—no—nothing.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Fie! Sir Samuel! Nothing to ſay to a lady!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: No!—Hem!—I never had any thing to ſay to ladies in my life! That is—Yes—Yes—I own—I have ſomething of the—the utmoſt—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A thing which—lies at my heart!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Mercy!—Sir Samuel!—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Which I—Hem!—Have long—But I will take ſome other opportunity. [Offering to go.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: By no means, Sir Samuel! You have quite alarmed me! I am impatient to hear! I am afraid you are troubled in mind—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why—Hem!—Yes, Madam—Rather—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I declare, I thought ſo! I am very ſorry! Perhaps you are afraid of death?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yet you are not ſo very old!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I would not have you terrify yourſelf too much—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I perceive I have gueſſed it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam! Hem! No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No!—What then is this important ſecret?—Nay, pray tell me—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! N—n—n—n not at preſent, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Some other time, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And can you be ſo cruel to me? Can you? I declare, I ſhall dream about you! Shall think I ſee you in your winding-ſheet! Or ſome ſuch frightful figure! And ſhall wake all in a tremble—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A tremble indeed, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And won't you tell me, Sir Samuel? Won't you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: N—n—n—n not at preſent, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, if you won't, Sir Samuel, I muſt leave you; for what you have ſaid has abſolutely given me the vapours!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I, Madam!—Have I given you the vapours?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, you have, Sir Samuel; and ſhockingly too! You have put ſuch gloomy ideas into my mind!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your ſalts, Lydia!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you—you are not very ill!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall be better in another room—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] Yes, yes; 'tis my company that has given her the vapours. [Aloud] Shall I— [Confuſedly offering his arm.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no—Stay where you are, Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] She wants to be rid of me!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Only, remember, you are under a promiſe to tell me your ſecret—Hem!—If you don't, I ſhall certainly ſee your ghoſt! Remember—Hem! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—I— [Not knowing whether to go or ſtay]— [To Lydia] Miſs Lydia—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: If you would—hem! be ſo civil, I—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! I have the vapours as bad as Miſs Lucy! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
Have you?—Hem! Bleſs me! Death! Winding-ſheets! Ghoſts!—Gloomy ideas indeed—Hem!—She was laughing at
me! I am ſure ſhe was! Hem! All my life long have I been laughed at by young coquettiſh girls! Yet I can't forſake 'em! Then the vapours! My old trick! I always give young ladies the vapours! I make 'em ill! They are always ſick of me! Hem!—'Tis very ſtrange that I can't learn to talk without having a word to ſay! A thing ſo common too! Why can't I give myſelf monkey airs, ſkip here and there, be ſelf-ſufficient, impertinent, and behave like a puppy, purpoſely to pleaſe the ladies? What! Is there no ſuch thing to be found as a woman who can love a man for his modeſty? This foreign count, now, my rival, is quite a different thing! He [Mimicking]—He walks with a ſtraight back, and a cocked-up chin, and a ſtrut, and a ſtride, and ſtares, and takes ſnuff, and—! Yes, yes! He's the man for the ladies! [Exit.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE, an Apartment in the Houſe of Sir PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: LYDIA.
sp.p: I CANNOT forget it—My father alive! And I of noble deſcent!—'Tis very ſtrange!—Hope, doubt, and apprehenſion are all in arms! Imagination hurries me beyond all limits of probability!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why do you thus ſeek ſolitude?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: To indulge thought.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Has your friend brought you bad news?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What has he ſaid?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Strange things!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Heavens!—What?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You would think me a lunatic, were I to repeat them.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia! I conjure you not to keep me on the rack!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I was enjoined ſilence, but I feel my heart has no ſecrets for you—Yet, you will laugh.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ungenerous Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; you will think me mad.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia, you are unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Am I?—Well then, I am told—Would you believe it?—I am told that my family is illuſtrious!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Good heavens!—'Tis true! I feel it is true! Charming Lydia, [Kneeling] thus let love pay you that homage which the world, blind and malignant, denies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Riſe, Edmund. Birth can at beſt but confer imaginary dignity; there is no true grandeur but of mind.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Some one is coming!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Aye, aye! Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I am all tranſport!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Huſh! Away!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My angel! [Kiſſes her hand.]

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A gentleman to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This ſudden return, Sir, is kind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I have bethought me. The moment is critical, and what I have to communicate of importance. Are we ſecure?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: We are. This is my apartment. [Lydia goes and bolts the door.] Have you ſeen the Count, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No. But I have written to him anonymouſly.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And why anonymouſly?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: To rouſe his feelings, wound his vanity, and excite his anger. His ſlumbering faculties muſt be awakened.—Is he kind to you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No. Yet I believe him to be generous, benevolent, and noble of heart; though his habitual haughtineſs gives him the appearance of qualities the very reverſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Worthy, kind girl!—You were born for the conſolation of a too unfortunate father!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Again you remind me that I have a father. Why am I not allowed to ſee him? Why am I not ſuffered to fly into his arms?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He dreads leſt his wretched and pitiable condition ſhould make you meet him with coldneſs.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! How little does he know my heart! Yet ſpeak; tell me, what monſter was the cauſe of his miſery?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The monſter Pride.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Pride!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your mother's pride, which firſt ſquandered his wealth, and next endangered his life.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: How you alarm me!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: A deſpicable diſpute for precedency was the occaſion of a duel, in which your father killed his antagoniſt, whoſe enraged family, by ſuborning witneſſes, cauſed him to be convicted of murder, obliged him to fly the kingdom, and with your mother wander under a borrowed name, a fugitive in diſtant countries.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens!—But why leave me ignorant of my birth?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
That, being unfortunate, you might be humble: that you might not grieve after happineſs which you ſeemed deſtined
not to enjoy. 'Twas the precaution of a fond father, deſirous to alleviate, if not ſuccour your diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! How I burn to ſee him!—Is he not in danger? Is his life ſecure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He himſelf can ſcarcely ſay. His enemies have diſcovered him, are hot in purſuit, and fertile in ſtratagems and ſnares. They know that juſtice is now buſied in his behalf; but juſtice is ſlow, and revenge is reſtleſs.—Their activity, I hear, is redoubled.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Guard, I conjure you, guard my father's ſafety! Let me fly to ſeek him! Conduct me to his feet!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He wiſhed you firſt to be informed of his true ſituation; leſt, knowing him to be noble, you ſhould expect to ſee him in all the pomp of affluence, inſtead of meeting a poor, dejected, forlorn old man.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: His fears are unjuſt; injurious to every feeling of filial affection and duty! The little I have I will freely partake with him. My clothes, the diamond which my ſuppoſed mother left me, whatever I poſſeſs ſhall inſtantly be ſold for his relief: my life ſhall be devoted to ſoften his ſorrows. Oh that I could prove myſelf worthy to be his daughter! Oh that I could pour out my ſoul to ſecure his felicity!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Forbear!—Let me breathe!—Affection cannot find utterance!—Oh! this melting heart!—My child!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My child!—My daughter!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Falling at his feet] Can it be?—My father!—Oh ecſtaſy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Riſe, my child!—Suffer me to appeaſe my melting heart!—Oh, delight of my eyes!—Why is not your brother like you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My brother! Who? Have I a brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The Count is your brother.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: 'Tis too much!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He is not worthy ſuch a ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The ſiſter of the Count! I!—Ah! Nature, thy inſtincts are fabulous: for, were they not, his heart would have beaten as warmly toward me, as mine has done for him!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I will make him bluſh at his arrogance. You ſhall witneſs his confuſion; which ſhall be public, that it may be effectual.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Would you have me avoid explanation with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes, for the preſent.—I mean to ſee him. Our meeting will be warm; but he ſhall feel the authority of a father.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If you are a ſtranger to him, I fear leſt—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, no. He knows me, but knows not all his obligations to me.—I have ſecretly ſupplied him with money, and gained him promotion; which he has vainly attributed to his perſonal merits. But I muſt be gone. My burthened heart is eaſed! Once more, dear child of my affections, be prudent. I have much to apprehend; but, ſhould the preſent moment prove benign, my future days will all be peace!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Who's there?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Without] 'Tis I!—Open the door!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I am buſy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Open the door, Itell you!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And does he take the liberty to come into your apartment?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, he will take any liberty he can.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why don't you open the door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You are ſurrounded by danger and temptation!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Have no fears for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Will you open the door, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Let him come in. [Lydia unbolts the door.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What is the reaſon, you dear little baggage, that you always ſhut yourſelf up ſo carefully?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You are one of the reaſons, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw! You need not be afraid of me!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'm not afraid of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why that's right. I'm come to talk matters over with you. My Lady's out—a wiſiting. [Mimicking]—The coaſt is clear. I have ſecured my graceleſs dog of a ſon—I ſuſpect—!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: But it won't do! Mind! Take the hint!—I've heard of an excellent houſe!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You are running on as uſual, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With a convenient back door!—I'll beſpeak you a carriage! Chooſe your own liveries! Keep as many footmen as you pleaſe! Indulge in every thing your heart can wiſh! Operas, balls, routs, maſquerades! Rotten Row of a Sunday! Town houſe and country houſe! Bath, Briſtol, or Buxton! Hot wells, or cold wells! Only—Hem!—Hay?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt not hear ſuch ribaldry.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed but you muſt, my dear—How will you help it? You can't eſcape me now! I have you faſt! No ſcapegrace ſcoundrel of a—! [Mr. Dorimont comes forward] And ſo—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Sternly] And ſo, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! [Pauſe] And ſo! [Looking round] Locked up together! You were buſy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, very, Sir! Perhaps you have a houſe yourſelf, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With a convenient back door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: So far from offering the lady ſuch an inſult, Sir, I am almoſt tempted to chaſtiſe that impotent effrontery which has been ſo daring.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!—You are very civil, Sir! And, as a return for your compliment, I am ready to do myſelf the pleaſure, Sir, to wait on you down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'll ſpare you the trouble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Though this Lady's reſidence here will be but ſhort, I would have you beware, Sir, how you ſhock her ears again, with a propoſal ſo vile!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Your caution is kind, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am ſorry it is neceſſary, Sir! What! The head of a houſe! The father of a family! Oh! Shame! He who, tottering on the brink of the grave, would gratify appetites which he no longer knows, by reducing the happy to miſery and the innocent to guilt, deſerves to ſink into that contempt and infamy into which he would plunge unwary ſimplicity.

div.stage: SCENE, the apartment of the Count, an elegant room, with chairs, ſopha, glaſſes, pictures, &c.
MAC DERMOT and PICARD, with a letter in his hand, meeting.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Picard; what have you got there?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Von lettre for Monſieur le Comte.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, give it me, and go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: No! I not go about my biſaneſs! My biſaneſs is to ſpeaka to you.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To me!—And what is it you want?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Mon argent! My vage an my congé! My diſmiſs!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: How, man alive!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: You are dee—dee factotum to dee Count. He ſuffare no ſomebody to ſpeaka to him; ſo I am come ſpeaka to you.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah now, and are you crazy? Quit the ſarvice of a Count! Your reaſon, man?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p:
My raiſon is you talka too moſh enough; he no talk at all! I follow him from France;
I yet live vid him by and by four month, he no ſpeaka to me four vord!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Vat den!—Je ſuis François, moi! I ave dee tongue for a dee ſpeaka; I mus ſpeaka; I vila ſpeaka! He not ſo moſh do me dee faveur to ſcold a me! I ave leave dee beſt Madame in Paris for Monſieur le Comte—Quelle Femme! Her tongue vas nevare ſtill! Nevare! She ſcold and ſhe clack, clack, clack, clack, clack, from all day an all night! Oh! It vas delight to hear!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: And ſo you want to be ſcolded?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Oui—I love to be ſcold, I love to ſcold; to be fall out an to be fall in—C'eſt mon gout—Dee plaiſir of my life! J'irai crever! If I no ſpeak I burſt!

sp.speaker: Mac. D.
sp.p: And is it you now, ſpalpeen, that would chatter in the priſence of the Count?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Shatter! Shatter! Ha! Vat you mean ſhatter?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Have not you roaſt beef and plum pudding?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Vat is roas beef, vat is plom boodin, gotam! if I no ſpeaka? I ave a dee Maſter in France dat ſtarva me, dat pay me no gage, dat leave a me tout en guenilles; all rag an tattare; yet I love him better as moſh! Pourquoi? [Affectionately] Helas! J'étois ſon cher ami! His dear fren! He talka to me, I talka to him! I laugh at his joke, he laugh auſſi, an I am both togeder ſo happy as dee prince! But dee Count▪ Oh! He as proud!—Ha!—Comme ça. [Mimicking.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Poh! Now—My good fillow, have patience.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Patience! Moi!—I no patience—If I no ſpeak I am enragé—I am French—I am Picard—Ven dee heart is full dee tongue mus run! I give you varn—Let my Maſta ſpeak, or I ſhall diſmiſſa my Maſta!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Here comes the Count! Stand back, man, and hould your tongue!

div.stage: [Enter the Count, followed by two Footmen, in handſome liveries. Footmen place themſelves in the back ground. Mac Dermot comes a little forward.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The more I reflect on my own infatuation, the more I am aſtoniſhed!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traverſing the ſtage] A man of my birth! My rank! So to forget himſelf!—Still ſhe is an angel!—But the family of a cit!—A brewer's daughter!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Gives him a forbidding look] The world contains not a woman ſo lovely!—Yet the vulgar, haughty, diſguſting airs of the mother! The inſulting familiarity of the father! And the free, unceremonious tone of the whole family!—I am faſcinated!"—Neither do they condeſcend to court my alliance! I muſt be the humble ſuitor: I muſt entreat, muſt ſupplicate permiſſion to degrade my noble anceſtors, who will abjure me, bluſhing through their winding ſheets!—I muſt petition, and fawn, and acknowledge the high honour done▪—No! If I do!—Yet 'tis falſe! I ſhall! I feel I ſhall be thus abject.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: If—I might be ſo bould—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: A letter for your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh!—What from the ambaſſador?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No faith, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha! The Ducheſs▪

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No, my Lord, nor the Ducheſs, neither.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Taking it] Who then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, that is more than I can ſay—But perhaps the letter itſilf can tell you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Un pauvre valet footaman, mee Lor—His ſhoe, his ſtocking, his habit, his chapeau, vas all patch an piece. And he vas—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aſide, interrupting him] Bo!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Throwing down the letter, blowing his fingers, and duſting them with his white handkerchief] Foh!—Open it, and inform me of the contents.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: His viſage, mee Lor—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: [In a pitiful tone] Mee Lor—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: 'Sblood, man—! [Stopping his mouth, and puſhing him back.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Makes ſigns to the footmen, who bring an arm-chair forward, and again ſubmiſſively retire] She is ever uppermoſt! I cannot baniſh her my thoughts! Do you hear?—Diſmiſs thoſe— [Waving his hand.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.—Hark you, ſpalpeens! [Waving his hand with the ſame air as the Count.] [Exeunt footmen.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: [Advancing] Monſieur le Comte—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [After a ſtare] Again!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: I ave von requéte to beg—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pay that fellow his wages immediately!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I tould you ſo! [Puſhing him away] Huſh! Silence!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Silence! I am no Engliſh! I hate ſilence! I—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Poh! Bodtheration! Be aſy!—I will try now to make your pace! [Puſhes him off, and then returns to examining the letter.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Inſolent menial!—Well, Sir? The contents?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, I am afraid the contints will not plaſe you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, as for the how ſo, my Lord, if your Lordſhip will but be plaſed to rade—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Didn't I order you to read?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be ſure you did, my Lord; but I ſhould take it as a viry particular grate favour, if that your Lordſhip would but be plaſed to rade for yourſilf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip's timper is a little warm; and—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Read!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well—If I muſt I muſt!—The perſon who thinks proper, at preſent, to addreſs you—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Interrupting] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Be pleaſed to begin the letter, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Begin? Sarra the word of beginning is here—before or after—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: `The perſon'?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mighty odd! [Throws himſelf in the arm-chair] Proceed, Sir.

p.q: The perſon who thinks proper, at preſent, to addreſs you, takes the liberty to inform you that your haughtineſs, inſtead of being dignified, is ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Starting up] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why now, I tould your Lordſhip!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traverſing the ſtage.] Go on!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With heſitating fear.] The little—merit—you have—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With a look.] The little merit I have? The little?—The little?— [Mac Dermot holds up the letter.]—Go on!

p.q: The little merit you have—cannot convince the world that your pride—is not—is not—is not—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is not what? [Sternly.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Fearful] `Impertinent.'

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Striking Mac Dermot.] Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Viry well, my Lord!— [Throwing down the letter] I humbly thank your Lordſhip!—By Jaſus! But I'll remimber the favour—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [More coolly] Read, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To the divle I pitch me if I do!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Conſcious of having done wrong] Read, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
No, my Lord!—Mac Dermot is a man!—An Engliſhman!—Or an Iriſhman, by Jaſus, which is better ſtill! And by the holy poker, if but that your Lordſhip was not a Lord
now!— [Pulling down his ſleeves, and clenching his fiſt with great agony.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Careleſsly letting his purſe fall] Pick up that purſe, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: 'Tis viry well!—Oh!—Well!—Well!—Well! [Lays the purſe on the table.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You may keep it—Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What!—I touch it!—No, my Lord!—Don't you think it!—I deſpiſe your guineas!—An Iriſhman is not to be paid for a blow!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With increaſing conſciouſneſs of error, and ſtruggling with his feelings]—I—I have been haſty—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, well!—'Tis viry well!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am—I—I am ſorry, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Softened] My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Emphatically] Very ſorry—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pray forget it! [Taking him by the hand] I cannot forgive myſelf.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: By the bleſſed Mary, then, but I can.—Your Lordſhip is a noble gentleman!—There is many an upſtart Lord has the courage to ſtrike, whin they know their poor ſtarving depindants hands are chained to their ſides, by writchedneſs and oppreſſion: but few indeed have the courage to own the injury!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I will remember, Mac Dermot, that I am in your debt.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
Faith, and if you do, my Lord, your mimory will be better than mine!—I have lived with your Lordſhip ſome years; and, though not always a kind, you have always been a ginerous maſter. To be ſure, I niver before
had the honour of a blow from your Lordſhip; but then I niver before had the ſatisfaction to be quite ſure that, while you remimbered yourſilf to be a Lord, you had not forgotten poor Mac Dermot was a man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, well! [Aſide, and his pride returning] He thinks he has a licence now to prate.—There is no teaching ſervants; nay indeed there is no teaching any body a ſenſe of propriety!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Did your Lordſhip ſpake? [Bowing kindly.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Give me that letter. And—take the money—It is yours.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip will be plaſed for to pardon me there.—If you think proper, you may give me twice as much to-morrow.—But the divle a doit I'll touch for to-day!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Wait within call.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Going] I niver before knew he was all togedther ſuch a jewel of a maſter! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis this infernal letter that cauſed me to betray myſelf thus to my ſervant!—And who is this inſolent, this raſh adviſer? May I periſh if I do not puniſh the affront!—Here is no name!—A ſtrange hand too!— [Reads] The friend who gives you this uſeful leſſon has diſguiſed his hand, and concealed his name—Anonymous coward!—His preſent intention being to awaken reflection, and make you bluſh at your own bloated vanity'—Intolerable! Or, if not, to prepare you for a viſit from one who thinks it his duty to lower your arrogance; and who will undertake the diſagreeable taſk this very day.—Will he? Will he?—Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Entering] My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If any ſtranger enquire for me, inform me inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Good-morrow, Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Slightly bowing, and with vexation to Mac Dermot] Why, where are my fellows? No body to ſhew the gentleman up?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh! You are too ceremonious by half, Count!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With quickneſs] A little ceremony, Sir, is the eſſence of good breeding.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Pſha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pſha, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ceremony, like fringe hiding a beautiful face, makes you ſuſpect grace itſelf of deformity.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do you hear, Mac Dermot?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: See that thoſe raſcals are more attentive!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with you, Count?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Muttering and traverſing] Count! Count!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You ſeem out of temper!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Strongly feeling his own impropriety] Oh dear! No—No—Upon my honour, no!—You totally miſtake—I aſſure you, you miſtake. I'm very glad to ſee you! I am indeed! [Taking him eagerly by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
I'm very glad you are. Though you have an odd mode of expreſſing your joy! But
you are one of the unaccountables! Caſt off this formality—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Very fine! [Biting his fingers] Formality, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Give the heart its genuine flow!—Throw away conſtraint, and don't appear as if you were always on the tenter-hooks of imaginary inſult!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I! [Aſide] This is damn'd impertinent! [Struggling to be over-familiar] You entirely miſconceive me! My character is frank and open! No man has leſs conſtraint! I even ſtudy to be, as it were, ſpontaneous!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I perceive you do!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Really, Sir!— [Aſide] Does he mean to inſult me?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I thought to have put you in a good humour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am in a good humour, Sir! I never was in a better humour, Sir! Never, Sir! 'Sdeath! A good humour, indeed!—Some little regard to propriety, and ſuch manners as good breeding preſcribes to gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Edm
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well, well, Count, endeavour to forget the gentleman, and—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! No, Sir: however you may think proper to act, that is a character I ſhall never forget.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Never, except at ſuch moments as theſe, I grant, Count.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: By—!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well gulped!—I had a ſort of a meſſage; but I find I muſt take ſome other opportunity, when you are not quite in ſo good a humour. [Going] I'll tell my ſiſter what—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—Your ſiſter!—My divine Lucy!—A meſſage!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: So! The magic chord is touched!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I—I, I, I,—I am afraid I am warm.—Your ſiſter you ſaid!—I doubt I—that is—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well, well, make no apologies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Apologies! No, Sir!—I did'nt mean—That is—Yes—I—My Lucy! My Lucy! What meſſage?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot well ſay myſelf. You know the madcap.—She bade me tell you, if I happened [Significantly] to ſee you, that ſhe wanted to give you a lecture.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed! [Aſide] I'm lectured by the whole family. [Aloud] On what ſubject?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll take pet again!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I, Sir!—Take pet!—My ſenſe of propriety, Sir— [Biting his lips.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why, ay? Your ſenſe of propriety, which, by the bye, my ſlippant ſiſter calls your pride, [Count in great agitation] is always on the watch, to catch the moment when it becomes you to take offence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You—You are determined I ſhall not want opportunities!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You miſtake, Count—I have a friendſhip for you.—Why, what a forbidding ſtare is that now! Ay! A friendſhip for you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I am not inſenſible of the—honour—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Yes, you are.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[With over-acted condeſcenſion] Sir, you are exceedingly miſtaken! Very exceedingly! Indeed you are! As I am a man of honour,
there is no gentleman whom I ſhould think it a higher—that is—Upon my ſoul—!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Is the Count at home, young man?

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: [Without] Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I hear my father! We have had a fracas; I muſt eſcape! If you will come and liſten to my ſiſter's lecture, ſo—Good-morrow! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis inſufferable! Never ſure did man of my rank run the gauntlet thus! No reſpect! No diſtinction of perſons! But with people of this claſs 'tis ever ſo—Hail fellow well met!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay! Hail fellow well met! Hay! You jolly dog! [Shaking him heartily by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hem! Good—Good-morrow, Sir! [Aſide] Here is another family lecturer!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Was not that young Mock-modeſty that bruſhed by me on the ſtairs?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: It was your ſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Good morning, Sir! [Mimicking] ſaid the ſcoundrel, when he was out of my reach.—Dammee! [With a kick] I would have ſhewn him the ſhorteſt way to the bottom!—Well—Hay! You have elegant apartments here!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With contempt] Very indifferent, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I ſhall remain in town for a fortnight, and am glad you live ſo near—We'll ſtorm the wine-cellar!—I hear you are no flincher!—Hay! When ſhall we have a ſet-to!
Hay! When ſhall we have a rory tory? A catch, and a toaſt, and a gallon a man!—But—Hay!—What's the matter?—An't you well?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With ſudden exceſs of affability] Oh, yes, Sir Paul! Exceedingly well, Sir Paul! Never better, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, that's right—I thought you had been ſtruck dumb.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! By no means, Sir Paul! I am very happy to ſee you! Extremely happy! Inexpreſſibly—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I knew you would—What ſay you to my Lucy? Hay!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Say! That ſhe—She is a phoenix! [In raptures.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Dammee, ſo ſhe is! What is a phoenix?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I adore her!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That's right!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The day that makes her mine, will be the happieſt of my life!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So it will—For I'll make youas drunk as an emperor! Hollo, there!—Get your maſter's hat—Come, come; you ſhall dine with me. [Locking him by the arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Dammee, I'll make you drunk today!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Did you ſpeak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To you? Why, what the devil! Do you think I ſpoke to your footman? [Quitting his arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Again endeavouring to be affable] Oh, no, Sir Paul! No! I—Pardon me—I—I was abſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Abſent!—I ſmell a rat—Your dignity took miff!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir Paul; by no means—No—I—That is—I will acknowledge, I am not very much accuſtomed to ſuch familiarities.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Are you not? Then you ſoon muſt be.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, Sir! A few leſſons from me will cure you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I am the man to make you throw off! I'll teach you to kick your ſtatelineſs down ſtairs, and toſs your pride, as I do my wig, behind the fire.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good breeding, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Good breeding, Sir, is a blockhead, Sir! None of your ſormal Don Glums! None of your grand pas for me! A friend, good fellowſhip, and t'other bottle! That's my motto!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: People of my rank diſtinguiſh—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Damn diſtinctions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: They make it a condition, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed!—Look you, my dear Count, either unbridle, or you and I are two. You tell me you love my daughter—She is the fineſt girl in England; and I believe the ſlut has taken a fancy to you. The match pleaſes me, becauſe it diſpleaſes my wife—And, except when you are riding your high horſe, I like you, Count.—Diſmount, and it's a match.—If not, turn the peg, and prance! I'm your humble!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] I'll not endure it! Racks ſhall not make me bend to this!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lucy is a wench after my own heart!—No piping, no pining, no ſobbing for her! I have a fine fellow in my eye—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! [Alarmed]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: None of your Sir Ramrod Grumble-gizzards!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: By Heavens! I would cut the villain's throat who ſhould dare impede my happineſs!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why ay! Dammee, now you talk!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The loſs of my Lucy would render me the moſt wretched of beings!

div.stage: Enter MAC DERMOT with the hat.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To be ſure— [Taking him again by the arm] Come, come! [Claps the Count's hat on his head] Dinner is waiting! I ſmell the haunch! It perfumes the whole ſtreet! Come along! I hate the ſhackles of ceremony! A ſmoking table, and a repleniſhed ſideboard, ſoon put all men on a level! Your hungry and thirſty ſouls for me! He that enters my houſe, always depoſits his grandeur, if he has any, at the door! [Sings]
"This brown jug, my dear Tom, which now foams with mild ale."

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well ſaid, old Toby! Oh! [Rubbing his hands.]

div.stage: [Exeunt. The Count making diſconcerted attempts to preſerve his ſtatelineſs, wiſhing to be familiar, ſcarcely knowing how to behave, and Mac Dermot enjoying his embarraſſment.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: SCENE I. The drawing-room of Sir Paul Peckham elegantly furniſhed, but hung all round with prints, chiefly caricatures.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I SHALL never recover from my ſurprize!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The Count your brother?—My ſiſter, my family, muſt be informed.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Not on your life, Edmund. So implacable are his enemies, that my father informs me an Exempt, bribed by them, has followed him to England.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Impotent malice! The laws will here protect him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! Who can ſay? The wicked cunning of ſuch life-hunters is dreadful!—I inſiſt therefore upon your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My Angel! Fear nothing! [Kiſſing her hand.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Placing herſelf beſide Edmund] Turn about!—Now me. [Holding out her hand]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh ſiſter! I am the happieſt of men!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And you appear to be very buſy too, with your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Did you but know!—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! I know a great deal more than you ſuſpect—Not but you ſeem to be taking meaſures to inform the whole houſe.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Placing herſelf between them] That you two are never eaſy apart.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Siſter—I—I muſt inſiſt that you ſpeak of this Lady with—with every reſpect!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Edmund!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Looking firſt at one and then at the other] Strange enough this!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Were I to tell you—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Aſide, and making ſigns] Very well!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Tell me what?—Why don't you tell me?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Pſhaw! No no—Nothing—I—I don't know what I am ſaying.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why ſurely you don't imagine your fondneſs for each other is any ſecret?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Siſter! I don't underſtand—Are you narrow-minded enough to ſuppoſe this young lady unworthy the hand of—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Of my brother?—No—To call my Lydia Siſter [Taking her hand] is one of the things on earth I moſt fervently wiſh.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My generous friend!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My charming girl!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But—then—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
There are now no buts! It will be an honour—I ſay, ſiſter, you—you don't know—In ſhort I muſt very earneſtly ſolicit you to treat
Miſs Lydia with all poſſible delicacy—I—I—I cannot tell you more at preſent—But I once again requeſt, I conjure, nay I—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hem!—Humph!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You—You underſtand me, ſiſter. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed I don't!—There now goes one of your Lord and Maſters! Take care of him! He'll make an excellent grand Turk— [Humorouſly burleſquing] Treat Miſs Lydia, I ſay, with all poſſible delicacy—And have I, Lydia, have I ſhewn a want of delicacy to my friend?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, no! My heart throbs with an oppreſſive ſenſe of your generous, your affectionate attention to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oppreſſive?—Well! This is the proudeſt world!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nay, I didn't mean—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! No matter!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Have you had any converſation with the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No—There has been no opportunity yet to-day—I am really afraid his pride is quite as abſurd as that of my good Mamma!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And your affection begins to cool.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—I—I can't ſay that—Heigho!—He has his faults.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Ardently] I hope he has his virtues too!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So do I—But how to cure thoſe faults?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If incurable, 'twould break my heart!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your ardor ſurpriſes me!—But, huſh!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[Bowing] I was afraid, Madam, love
would not have found ſo much as a moment to ſpeak its anxieties—Nay even now— [Looking haughtily toward Lydia.]

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Pointedly, and almoſt in tears] Sir, I—I am ſenſible of my own unworthineſs. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That lady, Sir, is my friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why are you ſurpriſed?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!—No—no, not ſurpriſed—There is a maxim, indeed, which ſays—Friendſhip can only ſubſiſt between equals.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But where is the inferiority?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You are above the poor, the pitiful idea, that wealth confers any claims?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Perhaps it does not, Madam. But beauty, underſtanding, wit, in ſhort, mind, confers ten thouſand! And in theſe I never beheld your peer!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Very prettily ſpoken, indeed! And I am almoſt perſuaded that you love me very dearly.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, I adore you!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, you are continually thinking of my good qualities.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Eternally, Madam! I think of nothing elſe!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: True—You never remember your own!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Were I totally inſenſible of my own, Madam, I ſhould be unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
You admire me even in my repreſentatives, my relations and friends! Affable to all, good-humoured to all, attentive to all, your politeneſs, eaſe, and urbanity extend to every
perſon for whom you think my heart is any way intereſted! Your paſſions are all ſubſervient to love!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; ſubſervient is the very word! They are all ſubſervient to love!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You never recollect the dignity of your deſcent, nor accuſe mine of meanneſs! You have too much underſtanding to plume your thoughts with turgid arrogance; or to preſume on the imaginary merit of an accident, which none but ignorance, prejudice, and folly, are ſo beſotted as to attribute to themſelves!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mankind have agreed, Madam, to honour the deſcendants of the wiſe and the brave.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: They have ſo—But you have too much native merit to arrogate to yourſelf the worth of others! You are no jay, decked in the peacock's feathers! You are not idiot enough to imagine that a ſkin of parchment, on which is emblazoned the arms and acts of one wiſe man, with a long liſt of ſucceeding fools, is any honour to you! Reſponſible to mankind for the uſe or the abuſe of ſuch talents as you feel yourſelf endowed with, you think only of how you may deſerve greatly; and diſdain to be that ſecondary thing, that inſignificant cypher, which is worthleſs except from ſituation!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
The feelings of injured honour, Madam, perhaps may be too irritable. They ſhrink from inſult, and ſpurn at contamination! Yet honour is the ſource of a thouſand virtues! The parent of ten thouſand glorious deeds! Honour is generous, ſincere, and magnanimous! The protector of innocence, the aſſertor of right, the
avenger of wrong! Yes! Honour is the patron of arts, the promoter of ſcience, the bulwark of government, the defender of kings, and the ſaviour of nations!—Indulge me then in cheriſhing a ſentiment ſo noble!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indulge?—Applaud, you mean! Honour with you never degenerates into oſtentation! Is never preſumptuous! Is no boaſter! Is eager to earn, but ſcorns to extort pre-eminence! Your honour is not that abject inflated phantom which uſurps conteſted claims, exacts ſubmiſſion which it does not merit, offends, irritates, and incites diſguſt, nay tarniſhes even virtue itſelf! You do not, under the word Honour, ſeek a miſerable cobweb covering for exorbitant pride!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, accuſation ſo pointed, ſo—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, now! Have not I been reading your panegyric?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My lady deſires you will come to her immediately, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Very well [Exit Footman].—I am a thoughtleſs, ſlighty girl! What I ſay can have but little meaning—Elſe, indeed, I would have ventured to have given you a word of advice—But—'Tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, you have ſtung me to the ſoul! If I am indeed what you deſcribe, 'twere time I ſhould reform.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I muſt be gone.—I have, I own, been wildly picturing ſomething to myſelf, which I greatly fear I could not love! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
And is it my likeneſs?—Surely it
cannot be!—Could not love?—Excruciating thought! [Exit after Lucy.

div.stage: Enter EDMUND, in haſte, and LYDIA from an inner chamber, meeting.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This moment gone—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Eagerly] Which way?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Through that door.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Running, ſtops at the door] Ah! 'Tis too late! The footman is telling him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Why are you ſo much alarmed?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The clouds are collected, and the ſtorm is coming!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lady Peckham has watched her opportunity: Sir Paul has dropt aſleep in his armchair; ſhe has ordered your ſiſter to her apartment, and has ſent to the Count to come and ſpeak with her; that is, to come and be inſulted, here in the drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I know not—I dread her intolerable tongue.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps were you to retire, and, when they grow warm▪ to interrupt them at the proper moment, the preſence of a third perſon might be ſome reſtraint on the workings of pride; of the violent ebullitions of which I am in great apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Had I but met the Count before he had received the meſſage!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here comes Lady Peckham. Begone!

div.stage: Enter Lady PECKHAM, followed by a Footman▪

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I have delivered your ladyſhip's meſſage, and the Count is coming.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: [Swelling] Wery vell!—Go you about your buſineſs, feller— [Exit Footman.] Your company is not vanted, miſs.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: So, Sir! They tells me, Sir, that you and my fooliſh huſband are colloguing together, for to marry my daughter! Is this troo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With his uſual polite haughtineſs] If it were, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do you know who Miſs Loocy Peckham is, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Except that ſhe is—your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And do you know who I am, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have been told, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Told, Sir! Told! Vhat have you been told? Vhat have you been told, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: That your ladyſhip was an honeſt wax-chandler's daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, Sir! The debbidy of his vard, Sir! A common councilman, and city ſwordbearer! Had an aldermand's gownd von year, vus choſen ſheriff the next, and died a lord mayor elect!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: With all his honours blooming on his brow.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
And do you know, Sir, that I deſigns Sir Samooel Sheepy, Sir, an Engliſh knight
and barrowknight, for the ſpouſe of my daughter? A gentleman that is a gentleman! A purſon of honour and purtenſions, and not a papiſh Jeſubite!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Of his honours and pretenſions I am yet to be informed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat, Sir! Do you mean for to ſay, Sir, or to inſinivate, Sir, that Sir Samooel Sheepy is not your betters?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If Sir Samuel himſelf, Madam, had put ſuch a queſtion to me, I would have replied with my ſword; or, more properly, with my cane.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Cane! Wery vell, Sir! I'll let Sir Samooel know that you threatens to cane him! I'll take care to report you! Cane quotha! He ſhall talk to you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let him, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Madam! Madam! At every vord—Pray, Sir, do you know that Sir Paul Peckham has had the honour to be knighted by the King's own hand?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have heard as much, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Madam, indeed!—And for you for to think for to look up to my daughter!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Up, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Up, Sir!—Pray, Sir, vhat are your purtenſions?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With great agitation] Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir? Vhere do you come from? Who knows you? Vhat pariſh do you belong to?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, I am of a family known to hiſtory, known to Europe, known to the whole univerſe!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ah! I believes you are better known nur truſted!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The names of Connolly and Villars, Madam, never before were ſo degraded as they have been in my perſon.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! I makes no doubt but you are a purſon that vould degurade any name!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Inſult like what I have received from you, Madam, no man that breathes ſhould utter, and eſcape death—But you are—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat, Sir? Vhat am I, Sir? Vhat am I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: A voman, indeed! Sir, I vould have you to know, Sir, as how I am a lady! A lady, Sir, of his Majeſty's own making! And moreover, Sir, don't you go for to flatter yourſelf that I ſhall beſtow the hand and fortin of Miſs Loocy Peckham upon any needy outlandiſh Count Somebody-nobody!
