My daughter, Sir, is for your betters!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, though ſcurril— [Recollecting himſelf] I ſay, Madam, though ſuch vul—ſuch accuſations are beneath all anſwer, yet I muſt tell you that, by marrying your daughter, if after this I ſhould ſink myſelf ſo low—I ſay by marrying your daughter, Madam, I ſhould confer an honour on your family, as much ſuperior to its expectations, as the ſplendour of the glorious ſun is to the twinkling of the worthleſs glow-worm.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhat!—Vhat!— [Enter EDMUND] Marry come up! An Iriſh French foriner! Not ſo good as von of our pariſh porpers! And you! You purtend to compare yourſelf to the united
houſes of the Peckhams and the Pringles! Your family indeed! Yourn! Vhere's your ſettlement? Yourn! Vusn't my great uncle, Mr. Peter Pringle, the cheeſemonger of Cateatonſtreet, a major in the Train-Bands before you vus born, or thought of?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Aſide] So, ſo! I'm too late! [Aloud] Let me entreat your Ladyſhip—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat! Hasn't I an ownd ſiſter at this day married to Mr. Poladore Spragges, the tip-toppeſt hot-preſſer in all Crutched Friars! Isn't my maiden aunt, Miſs Angelica Pringle, vorth thirty thouſand pounds, in the South Sea funds, every day ſhe riſes! And doesn't I myſelf go to bed, and get up, the greateſt lady in this here city? And for to purtend for to talk to me of his family! Hisn!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Very warmly] I muſt tell you, my Lady, you ſtrangely forget yourſelf, and expoſe your family to ridicule.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You muſt tell me, Sir! Vhy, Sir, how dare you have the temeracity for to come for to go for to dare for to tell me! Here's fine doings! Henpecked by my own chicken!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The Count, Madam, is a man of the firſt diſtinction, in his native country!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat country is that, Sir? Who ever heard of any country but England? A Count among beggars! How much is his Countſhip vorth?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I had determined to be ſilent, Madam, but I find it is impoſſible! [With vehement volubility] And, I muſt inform you, my family is as ancient, as exalted, and as renowned, as you have proved yours to be—what I ſhall not
repeat! That I am the heir to more rich acres than I believe your Ladyſhip ever rode over! That my father's vaſſals are more numerous than your Ladyſhip's vaunted guineas! That the magnificence in which he has lived looked with contempt on the petty paltry ſtrainings of a trader's pride!—And that in his hall are daily fed— [Stops ſhort, and betrays a conſciouſneſs of inadvertent falſehood, but ſuddenly continues with increaſing vehemence] Yes, Madam, are daily fed, now, at this moment, Madam, more faithful adherents, with their menials and followers, than all your boaſted wealth could for a ſingle year ſupply!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Are? At this moment, ſay you, Count?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I know you to be a man of honour, and that you cannot ſay what is not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I—I have ſaid, Sir. [Walking with great perturbation.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You have ſaid more in a minute nur you can prove in a year!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Warmly] Madam, I will pledge my life for the Count's veracity.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You pledge! Vhat do you know about the matter? I'll pledge that he has been telling a pack of the moſt monſtrous—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Forbear, Madam! Such inſult is too groſs to be endured, almoſt, from an angry woman! Dear Count—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Voman again! Wery fine! Wery pretty! Voman quotha! To be called a voman by my own witals!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] What have I done!— [With agony] A lie!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
As for you, Sir, I doesn't believe
von vord you ſay! I knows the tricks of ſuch ſham ſhevaleers as you too vell!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Walking away from her] Torture!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: But I'll take care to have you prognoſticated.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Damnation!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'll have you karakatoored in your troo colours! I'll have you painted in your father's hall; you and your vooden ſhoe ſhrug and ſnuffle ſcare-crows; your half dozen lank and lean ſhotten herring ſhadows; vith the light ſhining through 'em, like parchment at a vorkſhop vinder; grinning hunger over a diſh of ſoup-meegur, vith a ſecond courſe of frogs; and a plate of hedge-berries and crab apples for the deſſert! I'll depicter you! I'll not forget your waſſals!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] I can ſupport it no longer. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Catches him by the hand] My dear Count—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—I am a diſhonoured villain!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: There! There! He tells you himſelf he is a willin! His conſcience flies in his face, and he owns it!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [With great ardour and feeling] Madam! He is a noble-hearted gentleman! His agonizing mind deems it villainy to ſuffer inſult ſo groſs.—Sorry am I, Madam, to be obliged to tell you that, humble though your family is, the diſgrace with which you have loaded it is indelible! With anguiſh of heart you force me to repeat, I bluſh while I liſten to you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhy who ever heard the like of
this here now? Here's a prodigal ſon! Here's a regenerate reprobate! Here's a graceleſs Gogmagog! To purtend as how he's aſhamed of me! Me! A purſon of my carriage, connections, and breeding! I! Whoſe wery entrance, of a ball night, puts Haberdaſher's-hall all in a combuſtion!

div.stage: Re-enter the COUNT, deep in thought, and much agitated.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: [Seeing him] Marry my daughter, indeed!—Faugh! [Exit Lady Peckham.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Into what has my impetuous anger hurried me?—Guilty of falſehood!—I?—To recede is impoſſible!—What! Stand detected before this city madam! Whoſe tongue, itching with the very ſcrophula of pride, would iterate liar in my ear! No! Falſehood itſelf is not ſo foul!—Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mac Dermot—I—You—You have heard of the ſtate which formerly my father held; of his houſehold grandeur, of the hinds and ſervants whom he daily fed, and the train by which he was attended!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be ſure I have, my Lord.—Here, your dukes and your peers know nothing at all of ſtyle! Abroad, ſome hundreds ſtarve, that one may ate! But, in England, they have learned the trick of aich man ating for himſilf!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pſha! Liſten—The—The misfortunes that ſince have befallen us are little known in this country.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be ſure they are not, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nor—N—Hem!—Nor would I have them—D—D—D—a—Hem!—Do you underſtand me, Mac Dermot?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I—I would not be expoſed to the inſolent taunts of upſtart wealth.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith then, my Lord, you muſt not live in this city.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, but—attend to me—I—I would—I would have them think—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [After waiting] What, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traverſing the ſtage, ſtriking his forehead, and then returning] Mac Dermot—there are ſituations—I ſay, it may ſometimes be wiſe, at leaſt prudent—and—and—excuſable—Have not you remarked, Mac Dermot, that Lydia— [Short pauſe.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! To be ſure I have remarked, my Lord, that ſhe is a ſweet crater; that Miſs Liddy!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, but—Her influence in the family—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Now—if—if—Suppoſe you were—to take—an opportunity—Is ſhe proud?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Mild as mother's milk, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If ſhe were perſuaded—I ſay—Our family misfortunes—That is—No—No—The family magnificence—Do you comprehend me?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pſha!—Damnation! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
[Stands ſome time amazed] Why, now, am I Mac Dermot, or am I not?—The Divle!—He would have me take an opportunity
with Miſs Liddy!—Faith and I would very willingly do that—And perſuade her—Oh! Honey, but ſhe is not ſo aſy to be perſuaded! [Pauſes] To be ſure he muſt mane ſomething! [Pauſes again] Oh! Hona mon dioul! But I have it!—Ahoo! What a thickſcull have I been, all this while!—He is a little bit aſhamed to be thought poor, among this tribe of Balifarnians, who have nothing but their dirty guineas to boaſt of—And ſo he would have me perſuade—Oh ho!—Let me alone. There ſhe goes! I will be after—Bo! Fluſtration! There is that Mr. Edmund, now, cloſe at her heels!—The young royſter is always getting the ſweet crater up in a corner!—Take an opportunity? Sarra the opportunity there is for me to take!

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: MR. DORIMONT.
sp.p: PRAY, Sir, is the Count within?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count, Sir! And pray why may you aſk?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I want to ſpeak with him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Spake! Oh! The Count is not ſo aſy to be ſpoken with. Plaſe to deliver your meſſage to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Inform him I am come for an anſwer to my letter.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Letter, Sir!—What! The letter brought by a ſhabby footman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Ay, ay—Has he read it?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Read it! Faith, and it has been very well read! But pray, Sir, now, are you the writer?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With dread] Then take my advice! Make your eſcape!—'Tis very well for you my maſter is not at home!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Smiling] Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why ſo? Man alive! Have you a mind to be murdered?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Fear nothing. [Knocking heard.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With increaſing terror] By the holy phial but there he is!—Why, will you begone now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No—I will not.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Marcy upon my ſoul!—For the Lord's ſake, Sir!—Why, Sir, I tell you he'll have your blood! And won't you begone now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Lord Jaſus! What will I do? If he comes into this room, here will be murder!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Go—Tell him I am waiting for him.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Me tell him!—I warn you to begone! Remimber, I waſh my hands of your blood.—Make off!—Make off, I tell you, while I go and keep him to his own apartment! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To a footman croſſing] Hark you, young man! Tell the Count, your maſter, that the ſtranger, who wrote the anonymous letter to him, is here, waiting for an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The ſears of the ſervant ſtrongly ſpeak the anger of the maſter.—But that was what I partly feared, and partly wiſhed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Enraged without.] Where is the raſh, the audacious, [Enter COUNT] the inſolent wretch, who— [Aſide] My father!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I ſcarcely could have expected ſo kind a welcome, Sir! 'Tis exemplary!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Paſſion, Sir, is ſometimes guilty of improprieties—Pray pardon me!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I imagined— [Seeing Mac Dermot] How now, Sir! Begone!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why ſo? Let him ſtay!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Begone, or!—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And do you hear—I am not at home.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aſide, and going] Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Here will be murder! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What ſhould that mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—There are reaſons—I ought not to expoſe my father's ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Rather own, you ought not to bluſh at your father's poverty! Is this my reception? This the warm welcome of a duteous ſon?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo ſudden—Yet my heart feels an affection—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Which is ſtifled by your vanity! Your father is contemned, becauſe he is unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir. I do not merit a reproach ſo cruel. Contemn my father! You know me not.—Tell me, which way can I prove my reſpect and love?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: By openly acknowledging me: not by concealment; not by diſavowing me in the day of my diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Think, Sir, of your own ſafety!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What danger is there with people of honour? Preſent me to the family of Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Sternly] Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let me conjure you not to be too precipitate. You know not the vulgar pomp of new-made gentry; whoſe ſuffocating pride treats indigent merit, nay, birth itſelf, with the moſt imperious diſdain!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Talk not of their pride, but of
your own! You complain of others haughtineſs? You! In whom the vice is ſo intolerable, that you willingly would diſown your father!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: But, determined to be known for what I am, ſince you refuſe, I'll introduce myſelf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Sir! I entreat! I ſupplicate! On my knees, I conjure you to forbear!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes; pride, kneeling, conjures a father in poverty to ſuffer himſelf to be diſclaimed! Your mother's pride was my houſe's downfal: this ſhe has bequeathed to you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir— [Starts up at hearing]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Without] I tell you, I know he is at home!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Without] Upon my ſoul, Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! Why I ſaw him from my own window!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Here is Sir Paul! You know not, Sir, how much is at ſtake! I have not time to tell you now; but let my intreaties—!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Oh! How humble are the proud! But remember, I conſent only on condition that you reſtrain your arrogance. If, while I am preſent, any ſymptom— [Retiring back.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Sblood! I knew you were at home! But to inſtruct ſervants how to lie, with the moſt cool, compoſed, and barefaced impudence, is one branch of modern education.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Damn apologies. I have good news for you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I do believe, (God forgive me!) that my wife is growing reaſonable!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Does ſhe conſent?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes—To permit you to aſk her pardon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! Aſk pardon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Advancing] Yes, Sir; aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!— [Aſide] Zounds! Again!—Why, what the plague can he do here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir, your very humble.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide, and alarmed] What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurpriſed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes! You have a trick of taking people by ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Does he know him?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide, and then to the Count] Odd enough!—Who is this queer old fellow?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] All is ſafe!— [Aloud] Sir, the—the—gentleman [Aſide] What ſhall I ſay? [To Sir Paul] A gentleman, Sir, who—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A gentleman!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes—That is—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, ſome poor relation, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—A relation—The—the family eſtates have been under his management.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! Your ſteward?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No—Not abſolutely my—my ſteward—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, your land-bailiff, then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir—No—That is—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Does not ſeem to have made his fortune by his office! A little weather-beaten.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He is a man of the ſtricteſt probity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, his appearance is the pledge of his honeſty!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Aſide] I can perceive he is practiſing deceit! Oh vanity! But I will reſtrain my anger. The moment of open puniſhment is not yet come.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Croſſing to his father] Let me requeſt you, Sir, not to reveal yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Drily] Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Returning to Sir Paul] His oeconomy and good management are equal to his fidelity.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] Confounded odd all this, though! [Aloud] Well, Count, I have exerted my whole authority with Lady Peckham; and her ſon Edmund, who has more influence over her than any body elſe, is your friend. So be wary, do your duty, and the day is your own.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My duty, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Your duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] A damned ſtrange fellow! [Aloud] Is it not your duty, Count, to ſerve yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And would you contend about a word?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Very true, Sir!—You ſeem a—a plain ſpoken—a—Hem!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Significantly] Yes! I think it my duty to tell vice, and folly, the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!—You hear, Count?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: His punctilious pride is contemptible!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Half forgetting himſelf] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And Sir!—I repeat: do your duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] The moſt unaccountable! Hem!—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] I am on the rack! He will betray himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [To the Count] The old gentleman does not mince matters!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide to his Father] You will ruin me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Do as he requires, or I will feign no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lady Peckham is expecting you. Come, come; try whether you cannot put on a winning ſubmiſſive air.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] I ſhall burſt!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Submiſſive, Sir!—Remember!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I ſhall not forget, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You approve my advice, don't you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Entirely. The leſſon you give him, Sir, is a uſeful and a neceſſary one. I know him!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Fiends!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, Sir—You—have lived long in the family?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, don't be affronted!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul] Let us begone, Sir! I am ready to attend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] The blunteſt, drolleſt—!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: We are loſing time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, well; in a moment. [To Mr. Dorimont] Pray, under favour, what may be the amount of the Count's rent roll?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir! His rent roll, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, his rent roll—The nett produce of his eſtates?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why that queſtion to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Coming between them] For heaven's ſake, Sir Paul, let us go.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Sblood! What a violent hurry you're in all of a ſudden!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Endeavouring to force him away] Lady Peckham is waiting, Sir. I beg, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] The myſtery thickens!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, has the Count—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Interrupting] For the love of mercy, Sir, anſwer no queſtions; hear none, aſk none! I am frantic!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To the Count] Silence, Sir! [To Sir Paul] Has the Count ever talked of his eſtates?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Damnation!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And told you the amount?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—no—But, as you—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I muſt inſiſt, Sir, on going. [To Sir Paul.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
I'm not prepared, Sir, juſt now to anſwer your queſtion, of the rent roll. I have buſineſs, and muſt leave you; but I will
ſhortly give you the information you require. In the mean time, young gentleman, think on what has paſſed! Obſerve Sir Paul's advice, and act as becomes you. Put off your vanity—Be humble, and know yourſelf. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide fervently] Thank heaven he is gone!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Your ſteward is an odd one!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I tell you he is not my ſteward.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What is he then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I thought you taught every body to keep their diſtance; but he treats you with as little ceremony as— [Aſide] as he did me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; people do take very unaccountable liberties.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: But what brought him here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—He—Buſineſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, the family eſtates.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what do you know of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You appear to be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Um—No, no.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You had ſeen him before.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! Yes, I had ſeen him. Come, let us be going.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But permit me to aſk.

sp.speaker: "Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw!" Come, come—Lady Peckham is waiting.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I muſt own, Sir Paul, I meet with many mortifications. Your daughter is an angel. But there are certain things to which a man
of my rank muſt not, cannot ſtoop. Do you, Sir Paul, come to an agreement with your lady, and I am ready.— [Calls] Mac Dermot!—I'll return in a moment. [Retires.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Now, if the demon of ambition did not poſſeſs me, I ſhould never truckle to the ſelf-ſufficient airs of this man of rank! He has put a ſpell upon me!—I'll break with him this moment—Yet, if I do that, all is over. My authority is gone! Madam will be triumphant; and then farewel to ſubmiſſion!—Beſide, the honour of the alliance! Nobility! Precedence! A family ſo famous! 'Sblood! Who knows but my grandſon may be a Marſhal of France? [To the Count, who returns] Come, come, Count; let us begone. You muſt make your peace with my Madam.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Solicitation, Sir Paul, does not become me; it is a thing I have not been accuſtomed to. Do you ſpeak for me. Say all, ſay every thing you pleaſe. Your mediation will, I preſume, be ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Quite angry] Damn me if this is not beyond all human patience! After all I have done in your behalf! What! Would you have me and my whole family approach your footſtool, there preſent my daughter, and kneeling beg your highneſs to accept her? No, my haughty Count! Either my daughter is worth aſking for, or not worth having. Carry your pomp to a better market; I'll ſtoop to it no longer. Your ſervant, Sir! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[Following] Nay, Sir Paul—Muſt I endure this? Muſt I?—I! The deſcendant of an
ancient race! The rightful lord of athouſand vaſſals! Ought I to cringe in ſupplicatory baſeneſs, uſe ſervile diſhonourable adulation, bend to ſufflated wealth, act the paraſite to new-fledged pride, and petition where I ſhould command? No! Earth ſhould hide me rather! But that love, imperious love hurries me forward, with impulſe irreſiſtible! What! Wait, and fawn on Madam, and mince, and ſimper, and act the ſkipjack, and chatter to her parrot, and be of her opinion, and fetch and carry, and praiſe her taſte, and join her ſcandal, and laugh when ſhe laughs, and kiſs her monkey!—And to whom?—Oh! [Exit.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of SIR PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh, yes! Stabling for a hundred horſes! Open houſe all the year about! Sarvants five and twinty to the ſcore; all making work for one another!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then the Count, your maſter, ſhould be immenſely rich.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Should be? To be ſure he is. Don't I tell you—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; you tell me one thing at night, and another in the morning—You had forgotten the Colonel's pay!—And the ſecret ſupplies!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aſide] Faith, and ſo I had!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And pray was this all your own invention?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, as to that—And is it me, now, that you would have to betray my maſter?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, then, he bid you ſpread this report?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah now, did I ſay that?—Did I ſay that?—I tell you he bid me no ſuch thing!—What, and did you think, now, you could get that out of me? By St. Patrick, but I would bite off my tongue, if it ſhould dare to blunder out one word againſt ſo good a maſter!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Aſide] Honeſt, affectionate fellow!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aſide] Oh! Blarney!—She wants to be too cunning for me, the ſweet crater! And ſo, for fear of—Miſs Liddy, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I almoſt love him myſelf, for his love to his maſter.

div.stage: Enter SIR PAUL, followed by EDMUND.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I tell you, I have done with him. He is a pompous, inſolent coxcomb! The Great Mogul himſelf is a fool to him!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: All men have their foibles, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Damn his foibles. I have enough to do with my own! And, do you hear, Sir? [Significantly] Don't let me be troubled with any of your foibles either! You underſtand me. [Looking at both] I'll not be trifled with. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What has put him into ſo ill a humour?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The curſed ſupercilious haughtineſs of the Count. He has inſulted Sir Samuel Sheepy, too!

sp.speaker: "Lydia.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it; but that's a trifle.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
You are miſtaken. Sir Samuel's reſentment is very high; and, notwithſtanding
the ſervility of his manner, is more to be apprehended than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Surely you do not expect a challenge?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay, my love, I would not wiſh to terrify you.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But you have terrified me!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, brother, have you ſucceeded with my mamma?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I believe ſo—I can't tell—Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hear him on the ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well, warn him to be careful.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The old ſtory! The Count's pride. If he ſhould quarrel again with Lady Peckham, all will then be over!

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.p: You have put me quite in a tremor!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Going] I will inform my mamma, Sir, that you are here; and ſhe will be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: May I not, Madam, be indulged with one previous word?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; one, and but one. Inſtead of conciliating, I find your manners offend and diſguſt every one. Either caſt away your hauteur, regain the affections and conſent of my friends, and above all make your peace with Lady Peckham, or this ſhall be the laſt meeting of our lives! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Are you aware, Sir, of your danger? Sir Samuel, Sir Paul, Lady Peckham, all affronted!
Nay your beſt friend, Edmund, has this moment left the room to avoid you! Oh! Think on that lovely lady! And if you have any affection for her, for yourſelf, or for your father—recall your reaſon, diſcard your folly, and act with a little common ſenſe! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This is ſtrange!—My father?—She know my father?—And why am I ſchooled and tutored thus? What have I done? What is it they expect from me?—Do I indeed offend and diſguſt?—Which way? Has not love induced me to overlook all the high diſtinctions which honour holds ſacred? Nay, am I not now come on the moſt abject of errands?—Yet, to loſe her—! The laſt meeting of our lives!—They will abſolutely drive me mad among 'em!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam [Bowing]—When I laſt had the honour—of a—an interview with your ladyſhip, I—I am afraid—I might poſſibly be inadvertently betrayed into—ſome warmth.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, Sir, ſeeing as how my ſon tells me you are a real nobleman, and not von of the rifraff fortin hunting fellers, if ſo be as you thinks fit to make proper pologies, vhy, Sir, I—I—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To a lady, Madam, every apology may be made. Any conceſſions therefore—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, as for that there, I vants nothing but vhat is right and downright. And I ſuppoſes, Sir, you are wery villin to own that an outlandiſh foriner muſt think himſelf highly
honoured, by a connexion with an Engliſh family of diſtinction. Becauſe that I am ſure you cannot deny. And that it vus a moſt perumptery purceedin in you, being as you are but a Frenchman, or of an Iriſh generation at beſt, to purtend to the hand and fortin of Miſs Loocy Peckham, vithout my connivance.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: As I tells you, Sir, I am upright and downright. So do you, or do you not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—! I am ready to acknowledge that the charms of your daughter's mind, and perſon, are equal to any rank!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Her mind and purſon, indeed! No, Sir! Her family and fortin!—And I believes, Sir, now you are come to your proper ſenſes, you vill own too that no outlandiſh lord, vhatever, can uphold any comparagement vith the Peckham family and connexions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With great warmth and rapidity] Madam, though I am ready to offer every excuſe which can reaſonably be required, for any former inadvertency; yet, Madam, no conſideration whatever ſhall lead me—I ſay, Madam, my own honour, a ſenſe of what is due to my anceſtors, myſelf, and to truth—that is, Madam—No! The world, racks, ſhall not force me to rank my family with yours.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhy, Sir! Vhat is it that you are talking of? Rank my family vith yourn, indeed! Marry come up! No, to be ſure! I ſay rank! I knows wery vell vhat is my doo: and that there, Sir, is the thing that I vould have you for to know! And I inſiſt upon it, Sir, that you ſhall know it; and ſhall own that you
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
knows it; or, Sir, I rewoke every thing I have condeſcended to ſpecify vith my ſon! So do you, Sir, or do you not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—What, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do you depoſe, that outlandiſh foriners are all beggars, and ſlaves; and that von Engliſhman is vorth a hundred Frenchmen?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—Whatever you pleaſe. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Wery vell!—And do you purdict that this here city is the firſt city in the whole vorld?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I believe it is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Wery vell!—And that the Moniment, and the Tower, and Lununbridge, are moſt magnanimous and ſuperfluous buildings?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'll have no circumbendibus! Are they, or are they not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip is pleaſed to ſay ſo. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be ſure I does! Becauſe I knows it to be troo! And that the wretches in forin parts are all fed upon bran; ſeeing as how there is no corn?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: As your ladyſhip thinks! [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And that the whole country could not purwide von lord mayor's feaſt?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—Certainly not, Madam: they have few turtle and no aldermen.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Ah! A pretty country, indeed! No aldermen! And that it vould be the hite of
purſumption, in you, for to go for to ſet yourſelf up as my equal? Do you own that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Paſſionately] No, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No force, no temptation ſhall induce me ſo to diſhonour my great progenitors!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My ſwelling heart can hold no longer! Honour revolts at ſuch baſeneſs! Patience itſelf cannot brook a fallacy ſo glaring! No! Though deſtruction were to ſwallow me, I would aſſert my houſe's rights, and its ſuperior claims!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Wery vell, Sir! Waſtly vell, Sir! And I vould have you for to know, Sir, vhile my name is my Lady Peckham, I vill diſſert my houſes rights, and claims! That I deſpiſes all—! Ha, ha!—Ha! Wery fine, indeed! Am I to be ſent here to be hectored, and huffed, and bluffed, and bullied, and bounced, and bluſtered, and brow-beat, and ſcoffed, and ſcouted, and—! Ha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Recovering his temper and interceding] Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I a brought my hogs to a fine market! But I'll let 'em know who's at home!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My warmth, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Your honour and glory, indeed! And for to purtend for to ſend for me here, to palaver me over as I ſuppoſed—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am ready to own, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
But I'll rid the houſe of you! I'll take good care you ſhall have no daughter of mine! You may poſt off to your father's hall, and there ſtarve in ſtate. Varm it with a blaze of dried leaves, and ſtop up the gaps in the
ſhattered vinders, and old groaning doors, vith clay; then ſend your ſhivering waſſals, that ſtand jabbering behind your von armed vooden chair, to ſkin the ſheep that died of hunger and the rot, to make you a varm vinter ſurtout!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Still interceding] Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My daughter, indeed! I'll karakatoor you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Flames and fury! [Following, is met by Sir Samuel Sheepy, who ſhuts the door after him, and will not ſuffer the Count to paſs.] How now, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing] Sir, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What does this mean, Sir? Let me paſs!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A word or two firſt, if you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let me paſs! [Putting his hand to his ſword.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing, but reſolutely guarding the door] Sir I muſt humbly entreat—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Damnation!—What is it you want with me, Sir? Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: My name is Sheepy, Sir. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sheepy? [Aſide] So, ſo, ſo! Hell and the devil! At ſuch a moment as this!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I am told, Sir, I have ſome obligations to you, which it becomes me to diſcharge.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Not quite ſo well, Sir, as I could wiſh. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] Was ever man ſo tormented?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I am informed, Sir, that you have condeſcended to mention me, in my abſence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: You did me an honour, Sir. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Either ſpeak your buſineſs, and ſuffer me to paſs, or I will nail you to the door!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are ſo warm! [Bowing]—I have been told you were ſo good as to threaten to cane me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ay, Sir? By whom!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: By Lady Peckham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well; ſuppoſe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Twas kind of you!—Unluckily, I have not been much uſed to threatening meſſages, and am really afraid I ſhall not be very prompt at ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh, do not doubt yourſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Humble though I am, I do not find that a ſwaggering look— [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! [With his hand to his ſword.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Moderate your anger, kind Sir—I have a petition to you. [Putting on his white gloves.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Damn your ſneer, Sir! Speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir! You are ſo warm! It is only that you would kindly do me the favour either to cut my throat, or ſuffer me to cut yours. [Draws and flouriſhes.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With his hand to his ſword] Are you mad, Sir? Do you recollect where you are? In whoſe houſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
Gadſo! True, Sir! I ſhould be ſorry to be interrupted—Luckily, my carriage is at the door; and I know a ſnug room in a
neighbouring tavern, where this buſineſs may be effectually ſettled, as quietly, as coolly, and as privately as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twere well for you, Sir, had you choſen another opportunity—But come!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! I know my place—After you! [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Away, Sir! [Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the COUNT's Apartment.
A conſiderable noiſe of haſty footſteps without, and voices at ſome diſtance calling—"Here! Here!—This way!—Up, up!—Follow!"

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am purſued, beſet, and cannot eſcape!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Blood and thunder! Why what's all this? Oh! And is it you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith and that is more than I can tell. [Noiſe approaching—Here, here, I tell you! This room!] Why what the divle—!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am hunted! My liberty, perhaps my life, is in danger!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why ſure the Count would not—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Here! Take, hide this packet from the eyes of my purſuers! Don't loſe it; but, if you have any ſenſe of worth and honeſty, deliver it ſafe into the hands of Sir Paul Peckham!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Niver fear me, honey.

div.stage: Enter an EXEMPT, and two BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: That's the man. Seize him!

sp.speaker: Firſt Bail.
sp.p: Sir, you are our priſoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: On what authority, Sir?

sp.speaker: Firſt Bail.
sp.p: Authority, Sir? The authority of law, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: For what crime?

sp.speaker: Firſt Bail.
sp.p: As to crime, Sir, I can't tell; but for a trifling debt, of fifty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: At whoſe ſuit?

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: At mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yours? Vile wretch! Gentlemen▪ he is a ſpy: the creature of a foreign Court! I never had dealings with him in my life!

sp.speaker: Firſt Bail.
sp.p: We know nothing of that, Sir. He has ſworn to the debt.

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: No parleying; take him away.

sp.speaker: Firſt Bail.
sp.p: Ay, ay. Come, Sir. [They all three forcibly drag him out.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Going and without] Help! Reſcue! Falſe Impriſonment!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why what is all this now?—Poor ould gintleman!

div.stage: [Noiſe without at a diſtance—"Reſcue! Reſcue! Help!"]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Where is my ſhillalee?—Oh, by St. Peter and his crook, but I will be one among you, ſcoundrels! [Exit running.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: SCENE, The Houſe of SIR PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: EDMUND.
sp.p: BE pacified: you are too much alarmed.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If Sir Paul ſhould have let them paſs, what dreadful conſequences may have followed! Where can he be?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: He is here!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!—Where are they?—Has any thing happened?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Happened!—Dammee! I could not believe my own ears!—A ſilky Simon!—The Count was in a right humour—'Sblood! I had a great mind to have let him kill the old fool.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then they have not fought! Are they ſafe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, yes; they are ſafe enough—But do you know the amorous ſwain, his blood being heated, could only be pacified on condition that he might have another interview with Lucy!—I'm glad on't!—I'll go and give her her leſſon.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, leave him to my ſiſter, ſhe needs no inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No?—Gad, I believe not! She's my own girl! But clear the coaſt; he is coming!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I will go to Lady Peckham; and do you, Lydia, watch for the Count.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, ay. He is ſuddenly grown humble; apologized to me, and promiſed to come and plead with my lady. But away.

div.p: Well, Sir Samuel, you are here!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Aſide] And I half wiſh I was any where elſe, already.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And ſo you abſolutely have the courage to attack my Lucy? Ha, ha, ha! Why you are quite a hero! You fear neither man nor woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aſide] I wiſh I didn't—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, but don't begin to look ſo pitiful! She'll be here in a minute. Don't flinch! Stand to your guns! She'll not eaſily ſtrike! Ha, ha, ha! Die hard, my old boy!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What is the matter with me? I declare he has talked me into a tremble! Why ſhould I be ſo terrified at a harmleſs woman? I can't help it! A pair of beautiful eyes are flaming ſwords, which no armour can reſiſt!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bleſs me!—My heart is in my mouth!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You ſeem taken by ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—No, Madam—Yes, Madam. [With his uſual bows.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My Papa informed me you were waiting, purpoſely to diſcloſe this important ſecret.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—Yes, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Do you know that I have had you in my mind I don't know how often, ſince I ſaw you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Have you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, I have—'Tis a pity, nay indeed a ſhame, that ſo famous an Engliſh family as that of the Sheepy's ſhould become extinct.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—There is no danger of that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No!—Why it is too late in life for you to marry, Sir Samuel—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Yes, Madam. No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed! So you—! Well! I ſhould like to know your choice—Some ſtaid body, I imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I would not have her too old, and diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! I can aſſure you, Madam—She—Hem!—She is a very beautiful young lady.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You ſurpriſe me!—Oh! Then perhaps ſhe is ſome low-born girl, who has more pride than underſtanding, and is willing to ſacrifice her youth, and beauty, to the ſilly vanity of riding in a coach?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Quite—Hem!—Quite the contrary, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Then ſhe muſt be poor, and muſt think
of marrying you for the ſake of your riches, hoping you will die ſoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem! She is very rich.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Is it poſſible!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: And I ſhould flatter myſelf would not expect me to die too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! But ſhe will! Young women never marry old men, but with a wiſh to dance over their graves.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Perhaps the poor girl may—may have made a faux pas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! Her virtue is unſpotted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You amaze me! Young, rich, beautiful, and virtuous! What can her reaſon be for making choice of you? Why does not ſhe rather marry ſome youth, whoſe rare qualities reſemble her own?—Oh! I've found the ſecret at laſt! She's an idiot.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! No, Madam—No—Hem!—I am afraid ſhe has too much wit!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir Samuel, you are the moſt fortunate gentleman I ever heard or read of!—But are you ſure ſhe is in love with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! N—Not very, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
No!—Oh ho! I have unriddled it at laſt! You have been bargaining for her with her father, or her mother, or—Ay, ay! The poor young lady's conſent has never been aſked!—And would you be ſo ſelfiſh as to ſeek your own ſingle gratification, and be contented to ſee her condemned to miſery, pining to death for the youth ſhe loves, and juſtly deteſting the
ſight of you, as the wicked unfeeling author of her wretchedneſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! [Looking toward the door] Madam I—Hem!—I wiſh you a good evening.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Preventing his going] Another word, Sir Samuel. Have you ever talked to the young lady on the ſubject?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! I—Hem!—I have and—Hem! I have not.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You never made a direct propoſal?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I, I—Hem!—I can't very well tell.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I can.—With much folly and depravity, there is ſtill ſome virtue in you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam! [Looking how to eſcape.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Though you could form ſo unjuſt a project, you never had the courage to inſult the lady by an avowal of your guilt.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! Guilt, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, guilt—However, Sir, ſhe has perfectly underſtood your inſinuations.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She has infinite reſpect for filial duties. But, though ſhe would beware of offending her parents, I know her to be equally determined never to entail miſery on herſelf; nor to accept a huſband whom ſhe could neither eſteem, admire, nor love!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—I—Hem!—Your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Between him and the door] Not till you firſt promiſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Forgetting his fear] I'll promiſe any thing, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That you will not render yourſelf more ridiculous, by perſevering in ſo abſurd, ſo unjuſt a purſuit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: No, Madam! I'm quite ridiculous enough already!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, more, that you will not ſeek ſome leſs friended, more enſlaved, or more timid young creature, whom your miſapplied wealth might command.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Whatever you pleaſe, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But that you will rather apply your ſuperfluous hoards to the protection of youthful innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Suffer me but to depart, Madam, and I will bequeath my eſtates in perpetuity as you ſhall direct; I'll entail them on the Magdalen; or I'll advertiſe for marriageable men and maids, and you ſhall portion out my money among them! I'll—I'll do any thing, except marry, or go a courting!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why then, Sir Samuel— [Kiſſing his hand] There—That be your reward.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Poor Sir Samuel! This is the firſt time he ever forgot his bow. [Enter the COUNT.] Well, Sir! have you effectually made your peace with my mamma?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have done my endeavour, Madam—Would I were at peace with myſelf!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
And are you ſtill, Sir, under the dominion of prejudice ſo weak? Do you ſtill repent
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
of what you ſo long have deemed your condeſcenſion?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Far otherwiſe, Madam. There are beings ſo peculiarly favoured of heaven, and endowed with ſuch high perfections, both of body and of mind, that they are ſuperior to all the diſtinctions of men, among whom they walk angels upon earth! You are one of theſe! And my miſery is, I never can deſerve you!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may have ſtumbled, but this ſelfcondemnation ſhews it was but to riſe with tenfold ſtrength. Perſevere, and we will be ſevered only by death.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: At length, my dear Count, Lady Peckham is pacified. To ſtoop to her ill-placed pride, to overlook her prejudice, and to petition as you did, was noble in you. I have ſeconded your efforts, have pledged myſelf for your honour, and guaranteed your veracity.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you have ſtruck a dagger to my heart! I have been guilty of falſehood! That very pride, and that exalted, or I fear extravagant, ſenſe of honour, which ſhould have preſerved me from a ſtain ſo hateful, have daſhed me down the precipice!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'twas inadvertent; but rankling vanity, ſtrengthened by a purer motive, the trembling alarms of love, induced me to perſiſt; nay, a ſecond time to aid deception.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You did wrong—But which of us can ſay they never erred?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
Ay! Who will ſtand forth and affirm,
that, amid the rude whirl, the confuſed doubts, or the terrors of paſſion, they never once have been betrayed into your crime? For a crime I own it is; and with conſequences ſo wide, ſo pernicious, and ſo fatal, that, when it ſhall be extirpated from the earth, that moment man will be perfect! But, in this poor world's preſent ſtate, it is ſo far venial, that (painful, humiliating thought!) no—the nobleſt, the pureſt of us all, cannot ſtrike his heart, and ſay—I never was a liar!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Frail as we are, and hourly as the arts of falſehood are practiſed upon us, to our detriment, and often to our ruin, thoſe only are moſt free from guilt, who ſhake contagion ſooneſt from them; and, by the next ſublime effort of truth, ſcorning to ſhrink from ſhame, which is their due, in ſome ſort turn the vice itſelf to virtue.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: But what have you ſaid that—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Come, come! We muſt ſtrike while the iron is hot! We muſt take my Lady while ſhe is in the humour, ſince ſhe muſt neceſſarily be a party in our deeds. And firſt I have agreed, as you know, Count, that my daughter's portion ſhall be 80,000l. The remainder will chiefly reſt with you. What ſettlement do you intend to make? And on what eſtates?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: None, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have no eſtates.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Sir!—Why, what!—Zounds!—
After the enquiries I made, I cannot be ſo deceived! Are not you Count Connolly Villars?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A colonel in the armies of the Moſt Chriſtian King?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Recommended to me by Meſſieurs Devigny, the great merchants at Marſeilles?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, then, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: When I firſt paid my addreſſes to this lady, I imagined my rank and family were a ſufficient counterpoiſe to wealth.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ha! Gold in one ſcale, honour in t'other?—Flimſy ware!—No, no—Kick the beam—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But, ardent, violent, and eternal, as my love for your angelic daughter is, and muſt be, even the loſs of her ſhall not tempt me, any longer, to practiſe the leaſt impoſition.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, but, 's blood! The ſteward! The family eſtates!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have told you the truth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What's the matter, Lydia?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Poor Mr. Mac Dermot—!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What of him?—Any harm?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He has been in ſome fray, and is ſo bruiſed!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bruiſed! Where is he?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Below, with a packet, which he wants to deliver to Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Pray go to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A packet for me! [Going] I ſhall never hear the laſt of this from my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Brother, go to my mamma, and endeavour to keep her in temper. [To the Count] Be not dejected! I know my father's affection for me, and do not yet deſpair. [Exit after Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Charming, generous girl!—This poor Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He is afraid of ſeeing you. He ſays you will never pardon him, for having taken the part of ſome man, whom you threatened to murder!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I? I threatened to murder no man!—Will you, Madam, be ſo kind as to tell him I am here; and that I inſiſt on ſeeing him?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: With pleaſure. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Kingdoms ſhould not tempt me to paſs another day like this!

div.stage: Enter MAC DERMOT, with his left Arm in a Sling.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now, Mac Dermot! Where have you been? What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No great matter, my Lord—Only a little bit of a joint here. [Pointing to his arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Broken?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: A double tooth or two—Not much, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Much!—How?—What have you been doing?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Pitifully] I hope your Lordſhip won't be angry! [Enraged] But the raſcals ſazed him neck and heels!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Seized who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Paſſionately] He was as innocent as the babe unborn, my Lord, and he tould 'em ſo: [Rage] the dirty rapſcallions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Who are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Pitifully] To be ſure, he—he ſent your Lordſhip a—a viry impartinent letter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How? [The Count's perplexities and paſſions are here effectually rouſed, and increaſe through the ſcene.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: There were three of them. Niver did your Lordſhip ſet your two good-looking eyes on ſuch a pair of thieves!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, tell your ſtory ſtraight forward! What letter do you mean? Who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With great emotion] I hope your Lordſhip will forget and forgive! It would have moved the bowels of your compaſſion, to have ſeen the ould gintleman!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? What can he mean? What old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Enraged] The dirty ſhaberoons took him by the throat—My viry blood boiled!—Upon my ſoul, my Lord, I could not bear it! I hope you will forgive me! By the merciful father, I could not bear it!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tell me, this moment, who you mean!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: He came running back, out of breath, and aſked for your Lordſhip. And ſo, my Lord, [Pleading] being a fillow-crater in diſtriſs—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Came where?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
A couple of as ill-looking Tyburnturnpike bum-bailiffs as your Lordſhip could
wiſh! With a cowardly complotter at their back! It was he that came behind me with his ſhillalee, while I was hard at work with them both But the brave ould gentleman ſtepped in; ánd, by the Virgin's night-cap, but he gave him his doſe!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Once more, tell me inſtantly, what old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Conſidering his age, he is as active, and as brave a fillow, as ever handled a fiſt.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aſide] He cannot ſurely mean my father! Mac Dermot, I entreat, I command you to tell me of whom you are talking.

sp.speaker: Mac. D.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip had but ſeen the noble ould ſoul, I'm ſure you would have forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But what letter—?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! The divle burn the letter! Now, my Lord, don't mention it! Pray don't remimber it, your Lordſhip! Pray don't! By my ſoul, now, my Lord, he is a fine ould fillow! Oh! How he laid about him!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Was it the perſon who came this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Fear nothing! Speak.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, then, my Lord—To be ſure—it was he himſilf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And is he ſafe? Did you free him from them?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I could not hilp it! [Emphatically] I could not hilp it! By the holy footſtool, but I couldn't!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mac Dermot! [Taking him by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, well! A time will come—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Are you much hurt, Mac Dermot?—Here!—Hollo!— [Enter a Footman] Call a chair! Run for a ſurgeon and a phyſician! The beſt that can be procured.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: For me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: For you, my noble fellow!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Spare yourſelf the labour, young man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go! Do as I order you; inſtantly. [Exit Footman.] Mac Dermot, you muſt be put to bed!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To bed, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And loſe ſome blood!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, that will be a little too much! I've loſt quite blood enough already.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pray! I requeſt! I muſt have you do as I deſire! I would not have any ill happen to you, for the world!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! And the divle of ill or harm can happen to Mac Dermot, the while he has ſuch an a ginerous prince royal of a maſter! Though I believe, the beſt thing that could happen to me juſt now, would be a good ſupper, and a hearty tiff of whiſky punch.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not for the Indies!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, it was hard work; and has given me a very craving kind of a call.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: The chair is waiting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go, my good fellow! Obey me but this once, and I'll never act the maſter to you more.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, well, my Lord. But I hope your Lordſhip won't quite kill me with kindneſs. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [With the packet opened] So, Count, I find, after all your pretended raptures, you never wiſhed to marry my daughter!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why did not you retract like a man; and not make a paltry, falſe excuſe of poverty?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, I made no falſe excuſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How, Sir! Shall I not believe my eyes? Have I not bills here in my hand, drawn in your favour, for five hundred thouſand crowns?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: In mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: In yours! Given me this moment by your own ſervant.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Impoſſible, is it? Why, look you, here are the bills: and, hollo! [Enter Footman] Go you, Sir, and deſire Mr. Mac Dermot to come back.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stir not for your life, on ſuch an errand! He muſt not, ſhall not be diſturbed.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, my word, it ſeems, is not to be believed; nor perhaps the bills themſelves! But, Sir, though you vaunt ſo highly of being a man of honour, the trick was beneath a man of honeſty.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Here's a komakul kind of an obſtroperous perſon, that ſays he muſt ſpeak to the Count—You may come in, Miſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Ah! What, my friend the ſteward!
I am glad you are come! Never was ſo amazed in my life! Your maſter, here, has been telling me he has no eſtates!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My maſter, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The feelings of man cannot ſupport this open ſhame! [Croſſing to go.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Whither now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay! Talk to him! I'm in a miſt!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Suffer me to paſs, Sir. [Croſſes to the door] Speak the truth—Render me contemptible! Abhorrent! But make me not a witneſs of my own diſgrace!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay! Or dread a father's malediction!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: His Father! The plague! Hem!—Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Father, indeed! Vhat he! So, ſo! Here's a wirago! Here's a chouſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My Lady—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I thought vhat vould be the upſhot on't!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Madam. [Takes her aſide for a moment in dumb ſhew.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Spurred on by ſuppoſitions and conceits the moſt abſurd, wholly intent upon yourſelf, contemning others, exacting reſpect you did not merit, refuſing ceremony where 'twas due, protuberant with pride, yet poorly • arping at and holding idiot warfare with the pride of others, forgetful of the dignity of reaſon, but with tenacious graſp clinging to the ludicrous
dignity of birth, the heir indeed and firſt born of Folly, ignorance itſelf has mocked and taunted at you!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Wery troo! Give him his own!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! My Lady!—I wiſh he would give you your own a little! Not but it's right enough!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be ſure! I knows wery vell I am right

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your father too has been avoided, nay diſowned! Your father! Who for years has lived in indigence, that he might ſecretly ſupply your wants, ſupport you in ſplendour, and preſerve you from all the miſery of which he made himſelf the willing victim!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! You! Was it you? Oh! Ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your father was offenſive to your ſight! And what was it you deſpiſed? Why this poor garb! You wiſhed no kindred with virtuous poverty! Had I appeared in all my former ſtate, though knave or fool had been blazoned on my brow, yet, decked in the trappings of magnificence, I had received an open welcome. But, bleſt be my penury! Since it has been your puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Sir, wrung as my heart is by remorſe, and guilty as I know myſelf, for I have ſtill increaſe of guilt, no words can mitigate my crimes. Yet, though I have erred, I feel I have ſomething in me capable of good; and ſtrong propenſities to all the tender ties, the filial duties, and the ſeverer virtues which I have ſeemed to want; a mind which, once convinced, has ſtrength to ſhun and to ſubdue its maſter paſſion,
renounce its folly, and abhor its turpitude. Deep is my offence againſt you and nature! But let nature plead in my behalf. Here at your feet, repentant for my faults, I claim that pity which a father ſo good, and ſo affectionate, will not ſure refuſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Oh! No—For now you ſpeak like the ſon of my heart, the image of my brighteſt hopes! You have ſtood the fiery trial, and are pure!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy but hark you me, Miſter—Vhy vhat! You are not a Count too, to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy then—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: If a title can flatter your Ladyſhip, mine is ſomething higher.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am a Marquis.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: A Marquis! You! Vell! [Aſide] For an outlandiſh Marquis!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My Lady—!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well but the bills? [Holding them out in his hand.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: They are mine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yours, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Remittances for ſome recovered arrears.—But where is my brave protector? My hero!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Safe, Sir! Every care is taken of the generous fellow.—Is the phyſician come?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I have taken care of that. I have ſent him my own phyſician. Hem!— [Aſide] My cook!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You know not half his worth!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Which ſhall not go unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, by heaven!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: We have now the means; we no longer are oppreſſed and poor.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet are you not in preſent danger?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No. Malice has ſpent its laſt effort. Our ambaſſador has juſt ſent me the final deciſion of the judges: my ſentence is reverſed, my whole eſtates are reſtored, and the power of my perſecutors is at an end.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! Fortune! Oh! My Father!—And may I hope it?—My Lucy! May I—?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes! Hope every thing!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yours! Heart and ſoul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: She is a brave wench!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Hold a blow, if you pleaſe! Vhat! Am I nobody?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, to you a thouſand excuſes are due.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be ſure they are!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am conſcious of my paſt ridicule, and will no more contend with your ladyſhip, for prejudices ſo falſe and weak.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I knoo I vus right! I knoo you made yourſelf ridicolous! I told you ſo often enough!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my Lady!—But hark you, Miſs Lydia— [Significantly] And, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: A moment's patience, Sir.—Count! How ſhall I tell him?—My ſon! Look at this charming, this virtuous young lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] Zounds! What now?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I am conſcious of having treated her
with proud unkindneſs, at the very moment too, when I perceived ſhe was ſincerely my friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your friend!—Look at her! Does not your heart throb? Feel you not ſenſations more tender?—Are you not all doubt, allhope, all fear, all perturbation?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—What!—Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Can you not imagine?—Look at her, I ſay!—Behold her agitation!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mercy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Open your arms, your heart, to receive her—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! Madam! Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My deareſt, beſt of brothers! [Runing into his arms.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My friend! My Lydia!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! How culpable have I been!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] 'Sblood! Here's a pretty piece of buſineſs!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat's that you ſay, Sir? Miſs Liddy the Count's ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Troo! Vell, I purteſt I'm quite in a quandary!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul.] And now, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aſide] Yes, 'tis my turn now!—Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: While labouring to reclaim the follies of youth—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: We ought not to forget the vices of age.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! We'll talk of them after ſupper, Sir. [Looking round at Lady Peckham and the company.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Well, Sir, on condition—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! Any condition you pleaſe, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Leading Lydia.] My dear Father!—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My kind ſon! [Aſide] Sly raſcal!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul.] We ſhall want a houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! Ay, ay!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Somewhere in Mary-le-bone.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: With a—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! [Aſide to Lydia] Huſh! Don't mention the back door!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then we are all friends?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To be ſure—But, you may as well not tell Scapegrace!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Not a word of the new liveries!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Depend upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My ſiſter and my friend! Can it be?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Would you not wiſh it thus?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! Moſt ardently!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Chequered are the ſcenes of life. Pleaſure and pain, joy and grief, auſterity and laughter, intermingling, weave a motley web. Our prejudices are our puniſhments: they cling about us, warp our actions, diſtort our manners, render us the food of ſatire, the mockery of fools, and torture us, as wailing urchins are tormented to make ſport for boys. Error and folly impede the progreſs of perfection.
Truth alone can make men wiſe and happy. Myſelf the ſacrifice of falſehood and miſtake, feebly have I ſtriven to ſtem the torrent▪ and here my taſk, and here I hope my troubles end.

lg.l: THE curtain dropt, of courſe the author ſends
Me to ſalute our gen'rous noble friends!
To me you liſten, he politely ſays,
Whene'er I prattle, with a wiſh to praiſe.
For kindneſs ſo unceaſing may you be
As happy, ev'ry ſoul, as your applauſe makes me!
But to my text—The theme to-night is Pride:
Much have we ſaid—and much more have implied.
Our boldeſt ſtrokes are feeble, nor can ſhew
The child of Pride with half his genuine glow;
Of Pride, which can ſuch various forms aſſume;
Now riſe an emperor, now ſink a groom.
Mounted aloft, the wonder of his age,
With hackney coachmen furious war to wage;
Six ſwandown waiſtcoats ſwathe him into ſhape;
His legs all buckſkin, and his coat all cape;
With manners, looks, and language ſuch you'd ſwear
His tutor had been Piccadilly's Bear;
When moſt contemptible moſt hoping praiſe,
And only envious of the groom he pays;
Four dappled greys in front, behind three men;
Then only in his height and pomp of pride,
When Girl or Gambler's ſeated by his ſide;
Driving by day, dicing by night, his paſſion;
Such is the modern man of high-flown faſhion!
Such are the ſcions ſprung from Runny-Mead!
The richeſt ſoil, that bears the rankeſt weed!
Potatoe like, the ſprouts are worthleſs found;
And all that's good of them is under ground.
Of Pride one ſingle ſketch in crayons more.
Behold her torch! Hark! Thunder ſhakes the door!
The carriage ſtops; the footmen make a lane;
The feathers ſtoop, and enter Lady Jane:
Perfect in how d'ye do, drop, bob, and bow.
(Curtſeys, my friends, are out of faſhion now)— [To the Galleries]
Firſt to his Grace; next to the next of birth:
She none forgets—ſave genius, wit, and worth;
Whom if ſhe mark, 'tis with a modiſh ſtare,
To aſk who knows them? or, How came they there?
Now at the bank, in antichamber kept,
Where Pharaoh's hoſt twelve tedious hours had ſlept,
She ſeats herſelf, like palpitating lover,
Eager the laſt night's loſſes to recover.
No ſenſe of virtue, dignity, or ſhame:
Her greateſt pride her knowledge of the game.
That pride moſt piqued, moſt mortified, to ſee
A Nabob's wife ſtake larger ſums than ſhe!
And now three anxious hours have ſlipt away:
Three hundreds have been loſt, in piddling play.
No luck for her! Aloud freſh cards ſhe calls:
Her paſſions riſing as her pocket falls.
She punts: again ſhe loſes; and again!
Oaths quiver on her lip! She names the ten.
Stung to the ſoul, a deſp'rate ſett ſhe makes;
Till even the winning banker deals and quakes.
Ghaſtly ſhe pants, with horror in her eye,
To be the firſt the fatal card to ſpy.
The fatal card is turn'd, and ends the reign
Of Faſhion, Folly, Pride, and Lady Jane!
Here too we end; oblig'd ourſelves to own
Our pride is great—when we can pleaſe the town.
